title: b'ARCS 2022'
description: b'International Conference on Architecture of Computing Systems'
Categories: b'computer architecture' b'computer engineering' b'memory technologies' b'operating systems'
Call For Papers: b'\n=========================================================================\r                 35th GI/ITG INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON\r                 ARCHITECTURE OF COMPUTING SYSTEMS (ARCS)\r                            Heilbronn, Germany\r                         September 13 \xe2\x80\x93 15, 2022\r                      https://arcs-conference.org/\r                     C A L L   F O R   P A P E R S\r THIS YEAR\xe2\x80\x99S FOCUS:  Quantum Computing: The Dawning of a new Age?\r  =========================================================================\rOverview:\r The ARCS conferences series has over 30 years of tradition reporting\rleading edge research in computer architecture and operating systems. The\rfocus of the 2022 conference will be on quantum computing and its impact\ron the whole system stack spanning from hardware layer to the software\rlayer. This includes hardware architectures, programming models, runtime\renvironments, cross-sectional topics, and real-world use cases. In\raddition to the main conference, ARCS will host workshops and special\rtracks comprising topics like Organic Computing, operating systems and\rmiddleware for emerging system, or fault tolerance. More information on\rthe workshops can be found on the ARCS web page.\rThe proceedings of ARCS 2022 are planned to be published in the Springer\rLecture Notes on Computer Science (LNCS) series. A best paper and best\rpresentation award will be presented at the conference. This year the\rconference will be again a physical meeting with a social program. To\rensure a safest possible meeting for all participants, we will monitor\rthe Corona situation closely and will take all necessary protection steps\rfollowing government guidelines as well as extra measures as needed.\r  =========================================================================\rImportant Dates:\r Abstract registration deadline: July 20, 2022 (extended)\rPaper submission deadline:      July 27, 2022 (extended)\rNotification of acceptance:     August 21, 2022\rCamera-ready papers:            September 4, 2022\rConference:                     September 13 \xe2\x80\x93 15, 2022\r  =========================================================================\rTopics of interest are on a wide range of HW/SW aspects of "Advanced\rComputing Architectures" include (but are not limited to):\r Hardware Architectures\r* Control architectures for Quantum Computers\r* (3D) System-on-chip\r* Distributed systems\r* Multi- and many-core architectures\r* Heterogeneous computing\r* (Runtime) reconfigurable architectures\r* Advanced computing architectures\r Emerging memory technologies\r* Programming Models and Runtime Environments\r* Quantum programming languages, quantum compilers and optimizers\r* Domain-specific languages and programming models\r* Operating systems, hypervisors and middleware for homogeneous and\r  heterogeneous multi-/many-core computing platforms\r* System management including but not limited to scheduling, memory\r  management, power/thermal management, and RTOS\r* Architecture specific code generation and optimization\r* New tools for architectural simulation\r Cross-sectional Topics\r* Adaptive systems (energy aware, self-x technologies)\r* Pervasive systems\r* Autonomous systems\r* Mixed-criticality systems\r* Organic Computing\r* Approximate Computing\r* Support for safety and security\r  =========================================================================\rSubmission guidelines:\r Authors are invited to submit original, unpublished research papers via\rEasyChair: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=arcs2022\rARCS 2022 uses a double-blind reviewing system. Manuscripts must not\ridentify authors or their affiliation. When citing own work, it must be\rdone in a neutral form (i.e. avoiding "our", "we", "previous work" etc.).\rPapers must be submitted in PDF format, formatted according to Springer\rLNCS style and must not exceed 15 pages, including references, appendices\rand figures.\rDetails: https://arcs-conference.org/submission\r =========================================================================\rOrganizing Committee:\r General Co-Chairs\rCarsten Trinitis, Technical University of Munich Heilbronn, Germany\rMartin Schulz, Technical University of Munich, Germany\r Program Co-Chairs\rNikela Papadopoulou, Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden\rThilo Pionteck, Otto von Guericke University Magdeburg, Germany\r Workshop and Special Session Co-Chairs:\rStefan Lankes, RWTH Aachen, Germany\rJens Breitbart, Bosch Driver Assistance, Stuttgart, Germany\r Web and Publicity Chair\rLars Bauer, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), Germany\r Publication Chair\rThilo Pionteck, Otto von Guericke University Magdeburg, Germany\r\n'

title: b'ACM SUI 2022'
description: b'ACM Symposium on Spatial User Interaction (SUI) 2022'
Call For Papers: b'\nCall for Papers: ACM Symposium on Spatial User Interaction (SUI) 2022\r Virtual Conference, December 1-2, 2022 (http://sui.acm.org/2022/)\r *** Paper submissions due August 8, 2022 (23:59 AoE)\r We invite you to participate in the ACM Symposium on Spatial User Interaction 2022 (SUI). SUI will be held December 1-2, 2022 (virtually). We seek original, unpublished papers documenting research contributions, practice and experience, or systems and novel applications, from all areas of spatial user interaction. User interface evaluations are strongly encouraged for every publication in this venue. Specific topics of interest include:\rSpatial interaction techniques\rSpatial user interface metaphors\rSpatial input devices and technology\rInteraction in mixed, augmented, and virtual reality\rEvaluation methods for spatial user interaction\rCollaborative interaction in 3D space\rDesign and user experience (UX) for spatial user interaction\rApplications of human spatial perception to interaction\rAdaptive and perceptual-inspired spatial user interaction\rApplications of spatial UIs, such as games, entertainment, CAD, education\rGesture-based spatial interaction\rTangible spatial user interaction\rMulti-touch technologies for spatial user interaction\rDesktop interfaces for spatial interaction\rMultisensory and other novel forms of spatial user interaction\rSystem Contributions - We invite many types of research contributions, including interactive systems. However, evaluating systems that are built using existing techniques can be difficult. For example, a system can be built using a known machine learning technique but it can enable entirely new functionality. In this case, reviewers will need to judge the novelty of the new functionality that the system enables without penalizing the work for leveraging an existing technique. For reference, here\xe2\x80\x99s a paper about evaluating interactive systems that reviewers and authors may want to familiarize themselves with: James Fogarty (2017): Code and Contribution in Interactive Systems Research (https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~jfogarty/publications/workshop-chi2017-codeandcontribution.pdf)\r Important Dates\r All deadlines are 23:59 AoE.\rSubmission deadline: 8 August 2022\rNotification: 21 September 2022 \rCamera Ready: 14 October 2022\r Submission Instructions\r The symposium invites full and short paper submissions. Papers are of variable length, which should match the level of detail of description for the research contribution.\rFull papers (normally 8 pages, maximum 10; excluding references) should describe research or design work within the scope of spatial user interaction.\rShort papers (up to 4 pages; excluding references) should address the same topic, but may include preliminary results or conceptual ideas.\rFor submission, please follow these instructions:\rSubmissions must not be previously published or accepted for publication elsewhere and must not be under review by any other publication venue during SUI 2022\xe2\x80\x99s reviewing period. Double submissions will be desk-rejected without review. In doubt, contact the program chairs or include a properly anonymized version of the competitive manuscript as supplementary materials.\r All submissions should be prepared in the ACM SIG Proceedings format (https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template). For the Latex version, please use the sigconf template. We accept submissions in either dual-column or single-column ACM format; the page limits above are stated in dual-column format.\r Submitted papers must be anonymous for the double blind reviewing process. We strongly encourage you to not anonymize citations to your own works. These should not be omitted, but referenced in 3rd person. For example, you can write "In a study by Jones et al. [1]..." and reference your own paper, instead of "In my previous work [1]...", with the reference listed as "[1] Blank for review."\r Highly relevant references to accepted, but still unavailable (i.e., "in press") publications may be used, but should be included with author\xe2\x80\x99s permission as supplementary materials. These also must be anonymized!\r Submissions must be made through the online submission system. Please specify the following submission options:\rSociety: SIGCHI, Conference/Journal: SUI 2022, Track: SUI 2022 Papers\r(https://new.precisionconference.com/sui21a/)\r When designing and presenting user evaluations, please consider the following:\rUser interface evaluations using non-representative or homogeneous participant populations can lead to biased results and inaccurate conclusions.\r When performing user experiments, researchers should strive to use samples that are representative of the population for which the technology is being designed.\rIf non-representative samples are not possible to collect, the limitations of the population studied should be clearly discussed within the paper. \rIf non-representative samples are not possible to collect, care must be taken when making claims about the work.\r When reporting on user studies participant demographic information must be included so that future researchers understand the results based on the population studied. \r Publication\r Accepted work will be archived in the ACM Digital Library, and will be provided as open-access for the first month following the symposium. Please note that at least one author of each accepted submission will be required to register to present at the symposium. If no author is registered by the early registration deadline, the accepted work will be withdrawn from the proceedings and digital libraries.\r Please be informed of the following messages from ACM:\rBy submitting your article to an ACM Publication, you are hereby acknowledging that you and your co-authors are subject to all ACM Publications Policies, including ACM\'s new Publications Policy on Research Involving Human Participants and Subjects. Alleged violations of this policy or any ACM Publications Policy will be investigated by ACM and may result in a full retraction of your paper, in addition to other potential penalties, as per ACM Publications Policy.\r Please ensure that you and your co-authors obtain an ORCID ID, so you can complete the publishing process for your accepted paper. ACM has been involved in ORCID from the start and we have recently made a commitment to collect ORCID IDs from all of our published authors. The collection process has started and will roll out as a requirement throughout 2022. We are committed to improve author discoverability, ensure proper attribution and contribute to ongoing community efforts around name normalization; your ORCID ID will help in these efforts.\r Please visit https://sui.acm.org for the most up-to-date submission instructions and deadlines.\r Contact:\r Questions should be directed to the SUI 2022 Program Chair through email: \rprogram@sui.acm.org\rTabitha Peck, Davidson College, USA\rThammathip Piumsomboon, University of Canterbury, New Zealand\rBenjamin Weyers, University of Trier, Germany\rBest regards,\rTabitha, Tham, and Benni\r    \n'

title: b'CPP 2023'
description: b'Certified Programs and Proofs 2023'
Categories: b'formal verification' b'proofs'
Call For Papers: b'\nCertified Programs and Proofs (CPP) is an international conference on practical\rand theoretical topics in all areas that consider formal verification and\rcertification as an essential paradigm for their work. CPP spans areas of\rcomputer science, mathematics, logic, and education.\r CPP 2023 (https://popl23.sigplan.org/home/CPP-2023) will be held on 16-17\rJanuary 2023 and will be co-located with POPL 2023 in Boston, Massachusetts,\rUnited States. CPP 2023 is sponsored by ACM SIGPLAN, in cooperation with ACM\rSIGLOG.\r CPP 2023 will welcome contributions from all members of the community. The CPP\r2023 organizers will strive to enable both in-person and remote participation,\rin cooperation with the POPL 2023 organizers.\r IMPORTANT DATES\r * Abstract Submission Deadline: 14 September 2022 at 23:59 AoE (UTC-12h)\r* Paper Submission Deadline: 21 September 2022 at 23:59 AoE (UTC-12h)\r* Notification (tentative): 21 November 2022\r* Camera Ready Deadline (tentative): 12 December 2022\r* Conference: 16-17 January 2023\r Deadlines expire at the end of the day, anywhere on earth. Abstract and\rsubmission deadlines are strict and there will be no extensions.\r DISTINGUISHED PAPER AWARDS\r Around 10% of the accepted papers at CPP 2023 will be designated as\rDistinguished Papers. This award highlights papers that the CPP program\rcommittee thinks should be read by a broad audience due to their relevance,\roriginality, significance and clarity.\r TOPICS OF INTEREST\r We welcome submissions in research areas related to formal certification of\rprograms and proofs. The following is a non-exhaustive list of topics of\rinterest to CPP:\r * certified or certifying programming, compilation, linking, OS kernels, runtime\r  systems, security monitors, and hardware;\r* certified mathematical libraries and mathematical theorems;\r* proof assistants (e.g, ACL2, Agda, Coq, Dafny, F*, HOL4, HOL Light, Idris,\r  Isabelle, Lean, Mizar, Nuprl, PVS, etc);\r* new languages and tools for certified programming;\r* program analysis, program verification, and program synthesis;\r* program logics, type systems, and semantics for certified code;\r* logics for certifying concurrent and distributed systems;\r* mechanized metatheory, formalized programming language semantics, and logical\r  frameworks;\r* higher-order logics, dependent type theory, proof theory, logical systems,\r  separation logics, and logics for security;\r* verification of correctness and security properties;\r* formally verified blockchains and smart contracts;\r* certificates for decision procedures, including linear algebra, polynomial\r  systems, SAT, SMT, and unification in algebras of interest;\r* certificates for semi-decision procedures, including equality, first-order\r  logic, and higher-order unification;\r* certificates for program termination;\r* formal models of computation;\r* mechanized (un)decidability and computational complexity proofs;\r* formally certified methods for induction and coinduction;\r* integration of interactive and automated provers;\r* logical foundations of proof assistants;\r* applications of AI and machine learning to formal certification;\r* user interfaces for proof assistants and theorem provers;\r* teaching mathematics and computer science with proof assistants.\r SUBMISSION GUIDELINES\r Prior to the paper submission deadline, the authors should upload their\ranonymized paper in PDF format through the HotCRP system at\r https://cpp2023.hotcrp.com\r The submissions must be written in English and provide sufficient detail to\rallow the program committee to assess the merits of the contribution. They must\rbe formatted following the ACM SIGPLAN Proceedings format using the acmart style\rwith the sigplan option, which provides a two-column style, using 10 point font\rfor the main text, and a header for double blind review submission, i.e.,\r \\documentclass[sigplan,10pt,anonymous,review]{acmart}\\settopmatter{printfolios=true,printccs=false,printacmref=false}\r The submitted papers should not exceed 12 pages, including tables and figures,\rbut excluding bibliography and clearly marked appendices. The papers should be\rself-contained without the appendices. Shorter papers are welcome and will be\rgiven equal consideration. Submissions not conforming to the requirements\rconcerning format and maximum length may be rejected without further\rconsideration.\r CPP 2023 will employ a lightweight double-blind reviewing process following the\rprocess from previous years. To facilitate this, the submissions must adhere to\rtwo rules:\r(1) author names and institutions must be omitted, and\r(2) references to authors\xe2\x80\x99 own related work should be in the third person (e.g.,\r    not "We build on our previous work ..." but rather "We build on the work of\r    ...").\r The purpose of this process is to help the PC and external reviewers come to an\rinitial judgment about the paper without bias, not to make it impossible for\rthem to discover the authors if they were to try. Nothing should be done in the\rname of anonymity that weakens the submission or makes the job of reviewing it\rmore difficult. In particular, important background references should not be\romitted or anonymized. In addition, authors are free to disseminate their ideas\ror draft versions of their papers as usual. For example, authors may post drafts\rof their papers on the web or give talks on their research ideas. Note that POPL\r2023 itself will employ full double-blind reviewing, which differs from the\rlight-weight CPP process.  This FAQ from previous SIGPLAN conference addresses\rmany common concerns:\rhttps://popl20.sigplan.org/track/POPL-2020-Research-Papers#Submission-and-Reviewing-FAQ\r We strongly encourage the authors to provide any supplementary material that\rsupports the claims made in the paper, such as proof scripts or experimental\rdata. This material must be uploaded at submission time, as an archive, not via\ra URL. Two forms of supplementary material may be submitted:\r (1) Anonymous supplementary material is made available to the reviewers before\rthey submit their first-draft reviews.\r (2) Non-anonymous supplementary material is made available to the reviewers\rafter they have submitted their first-draft reviews and have learned the\ridentity of the authors.\r Please use anonymous supplementary material whenever possible, so that it can be\rtaken into account from the beginning of the reviewing process.\r The submitted papers must adhere to the SIGPLAN Republication Policy\r(https://www.sigplan.org/Resources/Policies/Republication/) and the ACM Policy\ron Plagiarism (https://www.acm.org/publications/policies/plagiarism). Concurrent\rsubmissions to other conferences, journals, workshops with proceedings, or\rsimilar forums of publication are not allowed. The PC chairs should be informed\rof closely related work submitted to a conference or journal in advance of\rsubmission. One author of each accepted paper is expected to present it at the\r(possibly virtual) conference.\r PUBLICATION, COPYRIGHT AND OPEN ACCESS\r The CPP 2023 proceedings will be published by the ACM, and authors of accepted\rpapers will be required to choose one of the following publication options:\r (1) Author retains copyright of the work and grants ACM a non-exclusive\r    permission-to-publish license and, optionally, licenses the work under a\r    Creative Commons license.\r (2) Author retains copyright of the work and grants ACM an exclusive\r    permission-to-publish license.\r (3) Author transfers copyright of the work to ACM.\r  For authors who can afford it, we recommend option (1), which will make the\rpaper Gold Open Access, and also encourage such authors to license their work\runder the CC-BY license. ACM will charge you an article processing fee for this\roption (currently, US$700), which you have to pay directly with the ACM.\r For everyone else, we recommend option (2), which is free and allows you to\rachieve Green Open Access, by uploading a preprint of your paper to a repository\rthat guarantees permanent archival such as arXiv or HAL. This is anyway a good\ridea for timely dissemination even if you chose option 1.\r The official CPP 2023 proceedings will also be available via SIGPLAN OpenTOC\r(http://www.sigplan.org/OpenTOC/#cpp).\r For ACM\xe2\x80\x99s take on this, see their Copyright Policy\r(http://www.acm.org/publications/policies/copyright-policy) and Author Rights\r(http://authors.acm.org/main.html).\r PROGRAM COMMITTEE\r Steve Zdancewic, University of Pennsylvania, USA (co-chair)\rBrigitte Peintka, McGill University, Canada (co-chair)\rReynald Affeldt, AIST, Japan\rTej Chajed, MIT, USA\rKoen Claessen, Chalmers, Sweden\rRanald Clouston, ANU, Australia\rLeonardo de Moura, Microsoft Research, USA\rXinyu Feng, Nanjing University, China\rDenis Firsov, Tallinn University/GuardTime, Estonia\rYannick Forster, Inria Nantes, France\rMilos Gligoric, UT Austin, USA\rStephane Graham-Lengrand, SRI, USA\rElsa Gunter, Univerisity of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, USA\rChris Hawblitzel, Microsoft Research, US\rChantal Keller , Universit\xc3\xa9 Paris Saclay, France\rMarie Kerjean, CNRS, France\rYoonseung Kim, Seoul National University, Korea\rKenji Maillard, INRIA, France\rC\xc3\xa9sar Mu\xc3\xb1oz, Amazon Web Services, USA\rLawrence Paulson, Cambridge, UK\rPierre-Marie P\xc3\xa9drot, INRIA, France\rAnja Petkovi\xc4\x87 Komel, TU Wien, Vienna\rCl\xc3\xa9ment Pit-Claudel, EPFL, France\rChristine Rizkallah, University of Melbourne, Australia\rCody Roux, AWS, USA\rKazuhiko Sakaguchi, University of Tsukuba, Japan\rAnna Slobodova, Intel, USA\rAaron Stump, University of Iowa, US\rRen\xc3\xa9 Thiemann, University of Innsbruck, Austria\rAmin Timany, Aarhus University, Denmark\rJosef Urban, CIIRC (Prague), Czech Republic\rViktor Vafeiadis, MPI-SWS, Germany\rYuting Wang, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China\rTjark Weber, Uppsala University, Sweden\r ORGANIZERS\r Dmitriy Traytel, University of Copenhagen, Denmark (conference co-chair)\rRobbert Krebbers, Radboud University, Netherlands (conference co-chair)\rBrigitte Peintka, McGill University, Canada (PC co-chair)\rSteve Zdancewic, University of Pennsylvania, United States (PC co-chair)\r CONTACT\r For any questions please contact the two PC chairs:\rSteve Zdancewic (stevez@seas.upenn.edu)\rBrigitte Pientka (bpientka@cs.mcgill.ca)\r\n'

title: b'CGO 2023'
description: b'ACM/IEEE International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization'
Categories: b'computer science' b'compilers' b'code generation' b'code optimization'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO) is a premier venue to bring together researchers and practitioners working at the interface of hardware and software on a wide range of optimization and code generation techniques and related issues. The conference spans the spectrum from purely static to fully dynamic approaches, and from pure software-based methods to specific architectural features and support for code generation and optimization.\r IMPORTANT DATES\r Paper Submission: September 2, 2022\rAuthor Rebuttal Period: October 26 - October 28, 2022\rPaper Notification: November 7, 2022\rArtifact Evaluation Deadline: November 28, 2022\rArtifact Evaluation Notification: December 20, 2022\r  TOPICS\r Original contributions are solicited on, but not limited to, the following topics:\r * Code Generation, Translation, Transformation, and Optimization for performance, energy, virtualization, portability, security, or reliability concerns, and architectural support\r* Efficient execution of dynamically typed and higher-level languages\r* Optimization and code generation for emerging programming models, platforms, domain-specific languages\r* Dynamic/static, profile-guided, feedback-directed, and machine learning based optimization\r* Static, Dynamic, and Hybrid Analysis for performance, energy, memory locality, throughput or latency, security, reliability, or functional debugging\r* Program characterization methods\r* Efficient profiling and instrumentation techniques; architectural support\r* Novel and efficient tools\r* Compiler design, practice and experience\r* Compiler abstraction and intermediate representations\r* Vertical integration of language features, representations, optimizations, and runtime support for parallelism\r* Solutions that involve cross-layer (HW/OS/VM/SW) design and integration\r* Deployed dynamic/static compiler and runtime systems for general purpose, embedded system and Cloud/HPC platforms\r* Parallelism, heterogeneity, and reconfigurable architectures\r* Optimizations for heterogeneous or specialized targets, GPUs, SoCs, CGRA\r* Compiler support for vectorization, thread extraction, task scheduling, speculation, transaction, memory management, data distribution and synchronization\r  CALL FOR TOOL AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE PAPERS\r In recent years CGO had a special category of papers called \xe2\x80\x9cTools and Practical Experience,\xe2\x80\x9d which was very successful. CGO this year will have the same category of papers. Such a paper is subject to the same page length guidelines, except that it must give a clear account of its functionality and a summary about the practice experience with realistic case studies, and describe all the supporting artifacts available.\r For papers submitted in this category that present a tool, it is mandatory to submit an artifact to the Artifact Evaluation process and to be successfully evaluated. These papers will initially be conditionally accepted based on the condition that an artifact is submitted to the Artifact Evaluation process and that this artifact is successfully evaluated. Authors are not required to make their tool publicly available, but we do require that an artifact is submitted and successfully evaluated.\r Papers submitted in this category presenting practical experience are encouraged but not required to submit an artifact to the Artifact Evaluation process.\r The selection criteria for papers in this category are:\r* Originality: Papers should present CGO-related technologies applied to real-world problems with scope or characteristics that set them apart from previous solutions.\r* Usability: The presented Tools or compilers should have broad usage or applicability. They are expected to assist in CGO-related research, or could be extended to investigate or demonstrate new technologies. If significant components are not yet implemented, the paper will not be considered.\r* Documentation: The tool or compiler should be presented on a web-site giving documentation and further information about the tool.\r* Benchmark Repository: A suite of benchmarks for testing should be provided.\r* Availability: Preferences will be given to tools or compilers that are freely available (at either the source or binary level). Exceptions may be made for industry and commercial tools that cannot be made publicly available for business reasons.\r* Foundations: Papers should incorporate the principles underpinning Code Generation and Optimization (CGO). However, a thorough discussion of theoretical foundations is not required; a summary of such should suffice.\r* Artifact Evaluation: The submitted artifact must be functional and supports the claims made in the paper. Submission of an artifact is mandatory for papers presenting a tool.\r  ARTIFACT EVALUATION\r The Artifact Evaluation process is run by a separate committee whose task is to assess how the artifacts support the work described in the papers. This process contributes to improved reproducibility in research that should be a great concern to all of us. There is also some evidence that papers with a supporting artifact receive higher citations than papers without (Artifact Evaluation: Is It a Real Incentive? by B. Childers and P. Chrysanthis).\r Authors of accepted papers at CGO have the option of submitting their artifacts for evaluation within two weeks of paper acceptance. To ease the organization of the AE committee, we kindly ask authors to indicate at the time they submit the paper, whether they are interested in submitting an artifact. Papers that go through the Artifact Evaluation process successfully will receive a seal of approval printed on the papers themselves. Additional information is available on the CGO AE web page. Authors of accepted papers are encouraged, but not required, to make these materials publicly available upon publication of the proceedings, by including them as \xe2\x80\x9csource materials\xe2\x80\x9d in the ACM Digital Library.\r Authors should carefully consider the difference in focus with the co-located conferences when deciding where to submit a paper. CGO will make the proceedings freely available via the ACM DL platform during the period from two weeks before to two weeks after the conference. This option will facilitate easy access to the proceedings by conference attendees, and it will also enable the community at large to experience the excitement of learning about the latest developments being presented in the period surrounding the event itself.\n\t'

title: b'IEEE-TCE-SS-CE with AI 2022'
description: b"IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics (TCE) - Special Section on 'Consumer Electronics with Artificial Intelligence \xe2\x80\x93 Part I'"
Categories: b'audio/video, signal processing' b'automotive and hmi' b'healthcare and iot' b'quantum and security'
Call For Papers: b'\nIEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics (TCE)\r Special Section on "Consumer Electronics with Artificial Intelligence \xe2\x80\x93 Part I"\r Call for Papers\r Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), and Deep Learning (DL) represent game changer technologies for Consumer Electronics (CE). In fact, they ever more represent the core of most CE products, and they are also changing the way these products are designed and engineered. As a matter of example, on the one side, AI, ML and DL support the most advanced audio/video systems and their embedded signal processing functionalities, or enable the necessary information handling required in any smart environment powered by Internet of Thing (IoT) and edge computing paradigms. On the other hand, modern solutions for security and privacy, automotive and next-generation vehicles, or entertainment, among others, strongly rely on AI, ML and DL since from their early conception and, afterwards, in any development step. Therefore, this Special Section of the IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics (TCE) will focus on innovative methods that have successfully showed the benefits of exploiting AI, ML, and DL with CE systems throughout their entire lifecycle. \r Topics of interest in this Special Section include (but are not limited to) AI, ML, and DL technologies used in designing, developing, and powering state-of-the-art:\r * Audio/video systems and signal processing solutions\r* CE for automotive and next-generation vehicles\r* Consumer systems for healthcare and wellbeing\r* IoT, Internet of Everywhere, edge computing and smart environments  \r* Quantum-supported CE \r* Security and privacy mechanisms for hardware and software CE systems\r* Extended reality (VR/AR/MR), HMI, entertainment and gaming \r Important dates\r * Submission of Manuscripts: 15 SEPTEMBER 2022\r* Notification to Authors (1st Revision): 15 NOVEMBER 2022\r* Submission of Revised Manuscripts: 15 DECEMBER 2022\r* Notification to Authors (2nd Revision): 15 JANUARY 2023\r* Final Versions Due: 31 JANUARY 2023\r* Publication scheduled on: Issues 1-2 of 2023\r Senior and Guest Editors\r * Fabrizio Lamberti, Politecnico di Torino, Italy (Senior Editor of IEEE TCE)\r* Alberto Cannav\xc3\xb2, Politecnico di Torino, Italy\r* Zaixing He, Zhejiang University, China\r* Lucia Pepa, Universit\xc3\xa0 Politecnica delle Marche, Italy\r* Chia-Mu Yu, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Taiwan\r Instructions for authors \r Manuscripts must be submitted online via ScholarOne Manuscript Central following the IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics instructions: https://ctsoc.ieee.org/publications/ieee-transactions-on-consumer-electronics.html\r During submission, the Special Section on Consumer Electronics Designed with Artificial Intelligence \xe2\x80\x93 Part I should be selected. A cover letter should be also uploaded specifying the Special Section the manuscript is being submitted to. \r Because of the strict timing of the review schedule, manuscripts that receive a \xe2\x80\x9cMinor revision\xe2\x80\x9d recommendation in the first round will be considered for publication in the context of this Special Section in the indicated issue(s). Manuscripts that will receive a \xe2\x80\x9cMajor revision\xe2\x80\x9d recommendation will be considered for possible publication as regular papers in a next journal issue. \r \n'

title: b'CyberICPS  2022'
description: b'8th Workshop on the Security of Industrial Control Systems & of Cyber-Physical Systems '
Categories: b'security' b'network security' b'cyber security' b'computer security'
Call For Papers: b'\nCyberICPS is the result of the merging of the CyberICS and WOS-CPS workshops that were held for the first time in conjunction with ESORICS 2015.\r Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are physical and engineered systems that interact with the physical environment, whose operations are monitored, coordinated, controlled and integrated by information and communication technologies. These systems exist everywhere around us, and range in size, complexity and criticality, from embedded systems used in smart vehicles, to SCADA systems in smart grids to control systems in water distribution systems, to smart transportation systems, to plant control systems, engineering workstations, substation equipment, programmable logic controllers (PLCs), and other Industrial Control Systems (ICS). These systems also include the emerging trend of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) that will be the central part of the fourth industrial revolution.\r As ICS and CPS proliferate, and increasingly interact with us and affect our life, their security becomes of paramount importance. CyberICPS intends to bring together researchers, engineers and governmental actors with an interest in the security of ICS and CPS in the context of their increasing exposure to cyber-space, by offering a forum for discussion on all issues related to their cyber security.\rTopics\r CyberICPS invites submissions that present innovative ideas, proof of concepts, use cases, and results from a variety of topics relevant to ICS and CPS, including (but not limited to) the following ones:\r     Security Governance\r    Security policies\r    Risk analysis and management\r    Vulnerability assessment and metrics\r    Awareness, training and simulation\r    ICS/CPS security standards\r    Privacy and Anonymity in ICS/CPS\r    Cyber crisis management\r    System and Network Security\r    Threat modeling\r    Security architectures\r    Access control\r    Malware and cyber weapons\r    Intrusion detection and visualisation\r    Defense in depth\r    Monitoring and real time supervision\r    Applied cryptography\r    Perimeter security\r    Safety-security interactions\r    Cyber security engineering\r    Secure communication protocols\r    Formal models for ICS/CPS security\r    Hardware Security\r    Resilient ICS/CPS\r    Application Security\r    Secure Firmware\r    Incident Response and Digital Forensics for ICS/CPS\r    Forensics in ICS\r    Incident Response\r    Accountability\r    Case Studies\r    Case studies in the energy, utility, chemical, transportation, manufacturing, and other industrial and critical infrastructure sectors.\r \n'

title: b'BPM - Journal First 2022'
description: b'BPM 2022 - Call for Journal First Subissions'
Categories: b'business process management' b'journal first'
Call For Papers: b'\nCall for Journal First Submissions at BPM 2022\r BPM 2022 organizes a journal-first track as part of the scientific programm. Authors of journal articles on BPM topics will be invited to present their work at BPM 2022 as part of a poster session. This way, the authors are given an opportunity to engage directly with the community and conference attendees benefit from a rich overview of recent research results in the field.\r # Scope\r For the Journal-First Track, we solicit submissions related to articles that have been accepted for publication by an esteemed journal and that meet the following criteria:\r - The article relates to the topics of the BPM conference as defined for the three research tracks: Foundations, Engineering, and Management.\r- The article was an original submission to the journal and not an extension of an earlier conference or workshop paper.\r- The article was accepted for publication by a journal between May 1, 2021 and April 30, 2022; the acceptance must have been publicly announced; and the article must be available at the publisher\xe2\x80\x99s website. The article must be in English. \r- The article has not been presented at, and is not under consideration for, journal-first tracks of other conferences.\r # Format\r Accepted submissions will be presented in a poster session as part of the BPM 2022 scientific programme.\r # Submission\r Submissions must be done electronically  via the BPM 2022 EasyChair submission site (Journal-First Track) and include:\r - Title and author information of the article\r- The original abstract\r- A link to the original publication at the journal\xe2\x80\x99s website\r # Evaluation\r All submissions will be evaluated by the track chairs in terms of their topical fit with the scope of the BPM conference, as well as the standing of the respective journal (including, but not limited to, the journal\xe2\x80\x99s impact factor and ranking results). \r # Key Dates\r Abstract submission: July 1, 2022\rNotification: July 10, 2022\rConference: September 11-16, 2022\r # Attendance\r At least one author of each submission accepted for the journal-first track must register and attend the conference to present the work. As the articles of the journal-first track have been published already, they will not be part of the BPM 2022 proceedings. The articles will be listed in the conference program and BPM 2022 participants will have access to the respective abstracts and a pointer to the original journal article.\r # Journal-First Track Chairs\r Amy Van Looy (Ghent University)\rMatthias Weidlich (Humboldt-Universit\xc3\xa4t zu Berlin)\n\t'

title: b'CPMAIforPM 2022'
description: b'Intro to CPMAI Methodology for Project Managers'
Categories: b'artificial intelligence' b'project management' b'machine learning' b'big data'
Call For Papers: b'\nCognilytica is hosting Kathleen Walch and Ron Schmelzer, Managing Partners at Cognilytica and their presentation \xe2\x80\x98Intro to CPMAI Methodology for Project Managers\xe2\x80\x99 on Tuesday, July 5, 2022 at 10 AM ET!\r Far too often, agencies, organizations, and consulting firms are running data and AI projects without taking the right steps to ensure their success. Agile and iterative approaches have become adopted best practices for application development projects, but why don\xe2\x80\x99t we have something similar when it comes to advanced analytics, big data, and AI projects? Without using best-practices approaches that standardize steps for data preparation, data identification, and data protection, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to achieve the success you\xe2\x80\x99re expecting, wasting money and resources, leading to failure.\r This session will walk through the Cognitive Project Management for AI (CPMAI) methodology to provide the foundation needed for project success, especially as you incorporate advanced analytics and AI projects. The CPMAI methodology is the established best practice for AI & ML projects, and increasingly will be demanded by organizations and agencies that plan to develop, procure, and deliver AI and advanced analytics projects. This session will provide real world examples of how CPMAI methodology allows individuals to gain the skills needed for AI project success.\r Be sure to stick around for Q&A at the end! Register and attend for free on the Cognilytica event website: https://www.cognilytica.com/CLNjk1ODl8MTg\r Agenda:\r- 10:00am \xe2\x80\x93 11:00am: Featured Presentation\r- 11:00am \xe2\x80\x93 11:30am: Your Q&A and Interaction\r\n'

Call For Papers: b'\nCognilytica is hosting Kathleen Walch and Ron Schmelzer, Managing Partners at Cognilytica and their presentation \xe2\x80\x98Avoiding Automation Failure: What, When, and Why Automate\xe2\x80\x99 on Tuesday, September 20, 2022 at 11:30 AM ET!\r For organizations who want to get started on their AI journey, a great first place to start is with automation. However, figuring out what to automate, why to automate, and what return on investment (ROI) automation will provide can be tricky. Figuring out how AI can be added to automation, can prove even harder. Instead of learning the hard way, learn lessons from others who have been successful in this path and take key steps to make your automation to intelligence journey a success.\r Join this webinar in the \xe2\x80\x9cAdvanced Process Management: From Automation to Intelligence\xe2\x80\x9d series as Cognilytica managing partners Kathleen Walch and Ron Schmelzer lay the frameworks and questions you need to answer to get started on your Automation to Intelligence journey including:\r - What is Automation all about?\r- Why do we Automate?\r- Different types of automation (Hardware vs Software)\r- Reasons to Automate: ROI and More\r- Questions to ask to make sure automation is the right solution\r Be sure to stick around for Q&A at the end! title: b'ConversationalAI 2022'

Call For Papers: b'\nEnterprise Data & AI is hosting guest speakers Utsav Shah, Business Head, APAC & Europe at Shaip and Aravind Ganapathiraju, VP, Applied AI at Uniphore \xe2\x80\xafand their presentation "Conversational AI \xe2\x80\x93 Revolutionizing the Information Age" on Thursday, July 14, 2022 from 12 PM - 1 PM ET!\r Conversational AI has made our day-to-day lives so much better and easier. As humans, we talk to one another using open-ended questions, but asking a colloquial question to a virtual assistant doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sound like a smart thing to do. Yet, they come up with the right answer \xe2\x80\x93 every single time. How?\r Conversational AI is powering the future of modern technology and facilitating enhanced communication between humans and machines. When designing a seamless digital assistant that works effectively and accurately, you should also be aware of the many developmental challenges you might come across. Join this engaging session to learn about the benefits and challenges associated with conversational AI, how this technology is evolving and stick around till the end for Q&A with Utsav and Aravind! title: b'AIProjectFailures 2022'
description: b'The Top Reasons for AI Project Failure - and What you can Do about it'
Categories: b'artificial intelligence' b'machine learning' b'technology' b'government'
Call For Papers: b'\nCognilytica is hosting Kathleen Walch and Ron Schmelzer, Managing Partners at Cognilytica and their presentation \xe2\x80\x98The Top Reasons for AI Project Failure - and What you can Do about it\xe2\x80\x99 on Tuesday, September 20, 2022 at 11:30 AM ET!\r Artificial intelligence and advanced data projects are gaining rapid traction. However, with all this interest and hype in AI, only a small percentage of AI projects are actually seeing success. Why are so many AI projects failing when they don\xe2\x80\x99t need to? With all the resources, great technology, and skilled talent put towards building AI projects, we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be seeing so much AI project failure, but up to 80% of AI projects are not being completed successfully or achieving critical success measures. Clearly it\xe2\x80\x99s not a technology or people problem, so what could be the main issues holding back AI project success?\r Leveraging experience with thousands of AI projects and experience through best-practices approaches to AI, Cognilytica shares in this webinar the most common reasons for AI project failures and the insights to be learned from those failures. In this webinar we will discuss common reasons we see AI projects fail, the risk of overpromising and underdelivering on AI capabilities, methodologies and processes that can guarantee a higher rate of success, and how to avoid the common traps and pitfalls that usually beset AI projects.\r Be sure to stick around for Q&A at the end! Register and attend for free on the Cognilytica event website: https://www.cognilytica.com/CLNzAyMzZ8MTg\r Agenda:\r- 11:30am-12:30pm: Featured Presentation\r- 12:30am-1:00pm: Your Q&A and interaction\r\n'

title: b'CFTC 2022'
description: b'The Difficulties and Limitations of Implementing AI at the CFTC and Beyond'
Categories: b'artificial intelligence' b'machine learning' b'technology' b'government'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe August 2022 AI in Government event featured guest speaker is Dr. Tamara Roust, Chief Data Officer at the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission and her presentation \xe2\x80\x98The Difficulties and Limitations of Implementing AI at the CFTC and Beyond\xe2\x80\x99 Wednesday, August 24, 2022 from 11:30 AM  - 1 PM ET!\r Most institutions necessarily institute artificial intelligence (AI) to solve individual use cases in their enterprise, a form of \xe2\x80\x9cfirst-generation AI\xe2\x80\x9d. A chess program, speech recognition, an algorithm to rapidly buy and sell financial products. These are straightforward applications of structured data problems. One of the chief difficulties is in getting understanding in the enterprise beyond these structured data cases, particularly in the domain of limited budgets. Once the \xe2\x80\x9cfirst generation AI\xe2\x80\x9d is implemented, successfully or not, the next step is more lateral movement \xe2\x80\x93 development of more standalone cases, rather than layering and refactoring to produce additional complexity, the neural nets and deep learning AI problem sets. \r Join this interactive session to learn some of the difficulties associated with implementing AI as well as the difficulties moving from \xe2\x80\x9cfirst generation\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9csecond generation\xe2\x80\x9d AI in order to achieve business process improvement by modifying data architecture to reflect how data is actually used.\r Be sure to stick around for Q&A with Dr. Roust! Register and attend for free on the Cognilytica event website: https://www.cognilytica.com/CLNjc0ODR8MTg\r Agenda:\r- 11:30 - 12:30pm: Featured Presentation\r- 12:30 -1:00pm: Your Q&A and interaction\r\n'

title: b'ExaMPI 2022'
description: b'ExaMPI22 - Workshop on Exascale MPI 2022 @ SC22'
Categories: b'high performance computing' b'message passing interface' b'hybrid programming' b'heterogeneous systems'
Call For Papers: b"\nExaMPI22 - Workshop on Exascale MPI 2022\r Sunday, November 13th, 2022 from 9:00 AM to 5:30 PM US Central Time\rDallas, Texas, USA\r *** Call for Papers ***\r Held in conjunction with SC22: The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis\r -------------------------------------------------------------------------------\rImportant dates\r-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\r Submissions open: June 1, 2022\rSubmission deadline: August 1, 2022, AOE\rAuthor notification: September 2, 2022\r -------------------------------------------------------------------------------\r The MPI standard and its implementations have proven to be both scalable and\rhighly capable of capitalizing on novel software and hardware technologies.\rHowever, trends towards increasingly heterogeneous compute nodes, networks\rwith powerful offloading capabilities, alternative programming models, and\rnon-traditional workloads present new challenges and opportunities for\rinnovation. The aim of this workshop is to bring together developers and\rresearchers to present and discuss algorithms, protocols, operations, and\rconcepts in message passing programming models that address these challenges\rand opportunities, with a focus on MPI in particular.\r The theme of this year's workshop is interoperability and support for\rheterogeneity in hardware and software. However, submissions targeting any\rrelevant topic are welcomed. Topics of interest include (but are not\rlimited to):\r   -- Design and development of scalable message passing collective operations.\r  -- Communication and architecture topology mapping interfaces and algorithms.\r  -- Innovative algorithms for scheduling/routing to avoid network congestion.\r  -- Integrated use of structured data layout descriptors.\r  -- One-sided communication models and RDMA-based MPI.\r  -- Support for heterogeneous compute devices and heterogeneous memory systems.\r  -- MPI multi-threading and threading requirements from OSes.\r  -- Interoperability of message passing and other programming models, such\r     as PGAS.\r  -- Integration of task-parallel models into message passing models.\r  -- Fault tolerance in MPI.\r  -- Utilization of `smart' or programmable offloading technologies.\r  -- MPI I/O.\r -------------------------------------------------------------------------------\rPaper submission and publication\r-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\r The workshop welcomes both research and position papers. Research papers\rshould be no more than 10 single-spaced pages (including figures, tables,\rand references) using at 10-point font on 8.5x11 inch pages (US Letter).\rPosition papers should be no more than 8 single-spaced pages (including\rfigures, tables, and references) using a 10-point font on 8.5x11 inch\rpages (US Letter).\r Templates can be found here: https://www.ieee.org/conferences/publishing/templates.html\r Submissions can be made at: https://submissions.supercomputing.org\r Direct link: https://submissions.supercomputing.org/?page=Submit&id=SC22WorkshopExaMPISubmission&site=sc22\r Instructions for preparing papers for the proceedings will be emailed to\rauthors of accepted papers.\n\t"

title: b'IWDW 2022'
description: b'The 21st International Workshop on Digital-forensics and Watermarking'
Categories: b'steganography' b'forensics' b'watermarking'
Call For Papers: b'\nIn the last two decades, the International Workshops on Digital-forensics and Watermarking (IWDW) have been established as a premier forum for researchers and practitioners working on novel researches, developments and applications of multimedia security. Following this tradition, the IWDW 2022 is aimed at providing a technical program covering the state-of-the-art theoretical and practical developments in the field of digital watermarking, steganography and steganalysis, fake media forensics and anti-forensics, and other multimedia-related security issues.\r IWDW 2022 is held by Guangxi Normal University and sponsored by Institute of Information Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences.\r Due to the ongoing global COVID-19 pandemic, IWDW 2022 is going to be held as a hybrid conference. That is, attendees from the Chinese mainland are requested to attend the conference in person, and the ones from other countries/regions who are unable to make a physical presence at the conference can attend it virtually.\r The topics of interest include but are not limited to:\r*Authentication, copyright protection, DRM, and forensics watermarking\r*Channel coding techniques for watermarking\r*Convolutional neural networks (CNN) and deep learning for multimedia security\r*Combination of data hiding and cryptography\r*Fake multimedia forensics and anti-forensics\r*AI generated multimedia and detection of them\r*Information theoretic, stochastic and capacity aspects of data hiding\r*Large-scale experimental tests and benchmarking\r*Deepfake videos and detection of them\r*Statistical and perceptual models of multimedia content for multimedia security\r*Reversible data hiding\r*Robust perceptual hashing\r*Security issues in multimedia protection, including attacks and counter-attacks\r*Steganography and steganalysis (Steganology)\r*Theoretical steganology\r*Media source forensics and identification\r Each submitted paper will be reviewed by at least 2 reviewers. There will be two prizes: one for the best paper and the other for the best student paper. The proceedings of IWDW 2022 will be published on the Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) by Springer.\r Paper Submission\rSubmitted manuscripts must not substantially overlap with the ones that have been published or are simultaneously under review by other journals or conferences. Submissions should be properly anonymized for double blinded review. Therefore, author names and their affiliations should be removed and language be adjusted to prevent easy identification.\r The submissions must be clearly presented in English, and made as a PDF file of no more than 15 pages. The templates are available at http://www.springer.com/computer/lncs?SGWID=0-164-6-793341-0. For more details and submission guidelines, please visit www.iwdw.site.\r The conference papers will be selected based on reviewer\xe2\x80\x99s feedback, including the originality, significance, relevance, clarity of presentation, correctness, etc. Should the paper be accepted, at least one of the authors need register and attend the conference to present the work.\r Important Dates\rPaper submission deadline: 20 September 2022\rNotification of acceptance: 18 October 2022\rSubmission of camera-ready versions: 10 November 2022\r General Chairs\rYun-Qing Shi, New Jersey Institute of Technology, USA\rShichao Zhang, Guangxi Normal University, China\rXianxian Li, Guangxi Normal University, China\r Technical Program Chairs\rXianfeng Zhao, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China\rZhenjun Tang, Guangxi Normal University, China\rPedro Comesa\xc3\xb1a-Alfaro, University of Vigo, Spain\rAlessandro Piva, University of Florence, Italy\r Organizing Chair\rJinyan Wang, Guangxi Normal University, China\r Contacts\rPaper submission: Dr. Hong Zhang, zhanghong@iie.ac.cn\rLocal arrangement: Dr. Chunqiang Yu, yu_chunqiang@126.com\r\n'

b'

11th International Conference on Data Mining & Knowledge Management Process (DKMP 2023)

March 18 ~ 19, 2023, Vienna, Austria

Due to the current COVID-19 pandemic, registered authors are now able to present their work through our online platforms.

Scope & Topics

11th International Conference on Data Mining & Knowledge Management Process (DKMP 2023)will provide an excellent international forum for sharing knowledge and results in theory, methodology and applications of Data Mining and knowledge management process. The goal of this conference is to bring together researchers and practitioners from academia and industry to focus on understanding Modern data mining concepts and establishing new collaborations in these areas.

Authors are solicited to contribute to the conference by submitting articles that illustrate research results, projects, surveying works and industrial experiences that describe significant advances in the areas of Computer Science, Engineering and Applications.

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to, the following

Data Mining Foundations

Parallel and distributed data mining algorithms, Data streams mining, Graph mining, spatial data mining, Text video, multimedia data mining, Web mining, Pre-processing techniques, Visualization, Security and information hiding in data mining

Data Mining Applications

Databases, Bioinformatics, Biometrics, Image analysis, Financial modeling, Forecasting, Classification, Clustering, Social Networks, Educational data mining

Knowledge Processing

Data and knowledge representation, Knowledge discovery framework and process, including pre- and post-processing, Integration of data warehousing, OLAP and data mining, Integrating constraints and knowledge in the KDD process, Exploring data analysis, inference of causes, prediction, Evaluating, consolidating, and explaining discovered knowledge, Statistical techniques for generation a robust, consistent data model, Interactive data exploration/visualization and discovery, Languages and interfaces for data mining, Mining Trends, Opportunities and Risks, Mining from low-quality information sources.

Paper Submission

Authors are invited to submit papers through the conference Submission System by October 20, 2022 . Submissions must be original and should not have been published previously or be under consideration for publication while being evaluated for this conference. The proceedings of the conference will be published by Computer Science Conference Proceedings in Computer Science & Information Technology (CS & IT) series (Confirmed).

Selected papers from DKMP 2023, after further revisions, will be published in the special issue of the following journals.

  • International Journal of Database Management Systems (IJDMS) - INSPEC, WJCI Indexed
  • International Journal of Data Mining & Knowledge Management Process (IJDKP)
  • International Journal of Web & Semantic Technology (IJWesT)
  • International Journal of Grid Computing & Applications (IJGCA)
  • Computer Applications: An International Journal (CAIJ)
  • Information Technology in Industry (ITII)

Important Dates

Submission Deadline: October 20, 2022
Authors Notification: December 20, 2022
Final Manuscript Due: December 28, 2022
'

Call For Papers: b'\nThe 15th edition of the Innovation in Language Learning International Conference will take place on 10-11 November 2022. \rThe objective of the Conference is to promote transnational cooperation and share good practice in the field of the application of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) to Language Learning and Teaching. The Innovation in Language Learning Conference is also an excellent opportunity for the presentation of previous and current language learning projects and innovative initiatives. \r Two days of inspiring sessions in the framework of a highly interactive onsite and online conference experience will be delivered. Enhanced digital contents will give participants greater access to learning, sharing and networking.\r All accepted papers will be presented on-site and on-line.\rInteractive Questions and Answers sessions will follow each paper presentation.\rPoster Presentation Sessions will also be held, on-site and on-line.\rNetworking Opportunities will be organized.\r Important dates:\r- 18 July  2022: deadline for submitting abstracts \r- 16 June 2022: Notification of acceptance / rejection of abstracts\r- 13 October 2022: Deadline for final submission of papers \r- 10-11 November 2022: Conference days\r All accepted papers will be published in the Conference Proceedings with ISBN, ISSN and DOI codes. The publication will be included in Academia.edu and indexed in Google Scholar. The Proceedings will be sent to be reviewed for inclusion in the Conference Proceedings Citation Index by ISI-Clarivate \xe2\x80\x93 Web of Science \r\n'

title: b'SIGITE 2022'
description: b'The 23rd ACM Conference on Information Technology Education'
Categories: b'education' b'IT' b'CS' b'ACM'
Call For Papers: b'\nAll submissions will be made electronically and should use the ACM Templates. A PDF or Word document should be submitted for all types of submissions. All submissions can be electronically uploaded to the EasyChair service: Click here to submit on EasyChair. (link for submission: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=sigite2022)\r Panel and workshop proposals should include author information, while all other submissions (papers, extended abstracts, and big ideas) should be anonymous, with all author information removed. Submissions must adhere to the page limits described below, and submissions that exceed the limits will be rejected without review. Authors must register for and attend the conference as specified below in order for their work to appear in the conference proceedings.\r The Conference Committee has elected to move to the single column ACM template increasingly used for journals and proceedings. It is simpler to manage and easier to read. Because the words on each page are not as dense as the two column format, the number of pages of papers and other documents has changed, but the word counts will remain the same. \r ACM Proceedings Single-Column Template:\r LaTeX (use \\documentclass[manuscript,review,anonymous]{acmart} in the sample-authordraft.tex file for single-column): https://www.acm.org/binaries/content/assets/publications/consolidated-tex-template/acmart-primary.zip \rOverleaf, for collaborative authoring (use \\documentclass[manuscript,review,anonymous]{acmart} for single-column): https://www.overleaf.com/latex/templates/acm-conference-proceedings-master-template/pnrfvrrdbfwt   \rMS Word: https://www.acm.org/binaries/content/assets/publications/taps/acm_submission_template.docx \rPoster Templates:\rWe recommend use of templates from the Center for Open Science found at https://osf.io/6ua4k/.\r Other Information\r PAPERS\rSubmissions will be no longer than ten pages and will undergo a blind peer reviewing process. Authors will have approximately 30 minutes for their presentation, including the question and answer period. Accepted papers must be presented by at least one author and will be published in the conference proceedings. In some circumstances remote presentations of accepted papers may be possible.\r This year, we have two tracks for the full paper submissions:\r Experience Track: This track accepts experience in IT educations, the topics include but not limited to: experience reports, teaching techniques, pedagogical tools, curriculum design, IT curriculum standards, and so forth.\rResearch Track: The papers in this track are expected to discuss and evaluate methods to improve IT educations, the topics include but not limited to: novel and effective teaching methods, evaluation of pedagogical approaches, teaching and learning models, informal learning, online or distance learning, studies about the engagement in ITE, issues of gender, diversity, and underrepresentation, educational data mining, technology-enhanced learning, and so forth.\rPANELS\rPanels allow experts to discuss a current topic of interest in information technology education or research. Panel organizers are responsible for selecting appropriate panelists to participate. A panel will normally have at most four panelists including the organizer. Panel submissions should include a list of panelists, their affiliations, a description of the topics, and a brief position statement from each panelist. All panelists are expected to attend the conference and participate in the panel. Panel proposals are limited to four pages and will be published in the conference proceedings.\r WORKSHOPS\rWorkshops allow presenters to provide a tutorial or hands-on exploration of a topic in which attendees are expected to actively participate. The workshop proposer is required to attend the conference. Workshop proposals are limited to four pages and will be published in the conference proceedings. Workshops are typically 90 minutes, however, you may specify that you would like your workshop to run for 2 back-to-back 90-minute sessions if desired.\r BIG IDEAS IN IT EDUCATION\rParticipants are invited to prepare big idea talks that present works that attempt to challenge traditional thinking and/or wherein authors are actively seeking feedback from the SIGITE community. Accepted talks will be presented in a session as a lightning talk where each author is given 10 minutes to present their big idea including feedback. In some circumstances remote presentations may be possible. Big idea talk proposals are limited to two pages. Accepted talks will be published in the conference proceedings.\r EXTENDED ABSTRACTS AND POSTERS\rManuscripts considered Work in Progress (WiP) can be submitted as an extended abstract not longer than four pages. Extended abstracts will be reviewed by the program committee for inclusion in the conference proceedings and will be presented as posters during the conference itself. We especially encourage submissions from MS and PhD students who would like feedback on their research efforts. Topics not yet mature enough to warrant a full paper may also be submitted for presentation as a poster. Authors of accepted abstracts and posters will be asked to present their ideas in the form of a poster using the following guidelines.\r Poster size should be 48\xe2\x80\x9d x 36\xe2\x80\x9d or less.\rAuthor(s) name(s), institution(s) and funding source(s) should appear on the poster.\rThe title should be properly capitalized with a minimum font size of 80 points.\rThe text should be written with a minimum font size of 18 points.\rAuthors are encouraged to use a poster template. We recommend use of templates from the Center for Open Science found at https://osf.io/6ua4k/.\rBoards and easels will be provided during the conference\rSubmission Schedule\r Full paper, Panels, Workshops\rSubmission Due: July 1\rNotification date: Aug 1\r Lightning Talks/Extended Abstracts/Posters\rSubmission Due: Aug 4\rNotification date: Aug 10\n\t'

title: b'CSoNet 2022'
description: b'The 11th International Conference on Computational Data and Social Networks'
Categories: b'social networks' b'network science' b'data science' b'algorithms'
Call For Papers: b'\nDear Colleagues,\r ** Please accept our apologies if you receive multiple copies of this CFP **\r CSoNet 2022 provides a premier interdisciplinary forum to bring together researchers and practitioners from all fields of big data and social networks, such as billion-scale network computing, social network/media analysis, mining, security and privacy, and deep learning and applications. CSoNet 2022 seeks to address emerging yet important computational problems, with a focus on the fundamental background, theoretical developments, and real-world applications associated with big data network analysis, modelling, and deep learning and understanding. The conference solicits theoretical, methodological, empirical, and experimental research reporting original and unpublished results on computational big data and social networks. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:\r Real-world Complex Networks Analysis\rTrends and Pattern Analysis in Social Networks\rRepresentation Learning on Networks\rBig Data Analysis\rMathematical Modeling and Analysis of Real-world Social Platforms\rNetwork Structure Analysis and Dynamics Optimization\rData Network Design and Architecture\rInformation Diffusion Models and Techniques\rSecurity and Privacy in Data Networks and Analysis\rEfficient Algorithms for Large-scale Data Networks Computing\rReputation and Trust in Social Media\rSocial Influence, Recommendation, and Media\rApplications of Complex Data Network Analysis\rEnergy Efficiency in Mobile Data Networks\rNatural Language Understanding and Applications for Social Media\rE-commerce and Social Media Marketing\rDeep Learning on Graphs and its Applications\rStock Market Prediction and Stock Recommendation with Social Media Data\rAnomaly Detection, Security, and Privacy in Big Data Networks\rAnalysis of Signed and Attributed Real-world Networks\rMultidimensional Graph Analysis\rAlgorithmic Fairness in Social Network Analysis and Graph Mining.\rSocially-relevant Analytics from Social Media Contents (e.g., Bias, Toxicity, etc.)\r Accepted papers will be published in Springer\xe2\x80\x99s Lecture Notes in Computer Science, and indexed by ISI (CPCI-S, included in ISI Web of Science), EI Engineering Index (Compendex and Inspec databases), ACM Digital Library, DBLP, Google Scholar, MathSciNet, etc. Also, extended versions of selected best papers will be invited for publication in the Journal of Combinatorial Optimization, IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering, and Computational Social Networks.\r Authors who are interested in the above topics can submit their unpublished work to CSoNet 2022. A clear indication of the motivation and comparison with prior related work should be presented. Simultaneous submission to a journal or another conference with refereed proceedings is not allowed.\r Submissions must adhere to the following guidelines:\r Papers must be formatted using the LNCS format (ftp://ftp.springernature.com/cs-proceeding/llncs/llncs2e.zip) without altering margins or the font point.\rThe maximum length of a regular paper (including references) is 12 pages; 2 pages for an extended abstract.\rProofs omitted due to space constraints must be placed in an appendix to be read by the program committee members at their discretion.\rSubmission link: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=csonet2021\r Organizing Committee\r General Chair\rXiaofeng Gao\rShanghai JiaoTong University\r Program Co-chairs\rMinming Li, City University of Hong Kong\rThang N. Dinh, Virginia Commonwealth University\r Publicity Chair\rQin Hu\rIndiana University\xe2\x80\x93Purdue University Indianapolis\r Steering Committee\rMy T. Thai (Chair) \xe2\x80\x93 University of Florida\rKim-Kwang Raymond Choo \xe2\x80\x93 University of Texas at San Antonio\rZhi-Li Zhang, University of Minnesota\rWeili Wu, University of Texas, Dallas\r Important Dates:\r Paper Submission August 14, 2022\rAcceptance Notification September 10, 2022\rCamera Ready & Registration September 24, 2022\rConference Dates December 5-7, 2022\r Conference Mode of Operation:\r The conference is planned as a fully virtual conference. More Information about the conference and the organizers is available at http://optnetsci.cise.ufl.edu/CSoNet/\n\t'

title: b'SI Call For Papers 2022'
description: b'Special Issue: Modeling and Simulation of Floating Offshore Wind Farms'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe new future of power production within the wind energy sector is floating offshore wind farms. This emerging technology is opening new possibilities for wind power locations and will play a critical role in the transition to a cleaner energy supply, contributing significantly to an increase in wind power. However, the challenges faced in developing this new technology are significant, and outstanding research and innovation are required in areas such as design, energy extraction, installation, maintenance, monitoring, etc., to minimize risks and maximize the chances of a successful future installations.\r This Special Issue aims to address the challenges the floating offshore wind turbines sector is facing by providing innovative research ideas and reporting current advances in the field of modeling and simulation of wind farms. Contributions across a broad spectrum of scientific and engineering disciplines concerned with technological developments in offshore wind power generation, energy conversion, and integration are of great importance for the journal.\r This Special Issue seeks to disseminate knowledge on various aspects of offshore wind farm modeling and simulation and promote fundamental, multidisciplinary, and applied research in the field. This Special Issue offers a significant opportunity for reporting advancements in the field that can help to realize the potential of floating offshore wind farms. This Special Issue covers but is not limited to a wide range of topics, including:\r offshore wind farms\rdigital twins\rcost modeling\rmooring systems\rwind resource\rfluid surface interaction\rwind\xe2\x80\x93wave interaction\rocean\xe2\x80\x93currents\rwind float foundation technology\rmarine infrastructure\rwake dynamics and steering\rfloating platform design\rcontrol mechanisms\rsite selection\rreduced-order modeling\rapplications and economics\raeroelasticity and aeroacoustics\renvironmental and legal aspects\rwind turbine aerodynamics\rinstallation and condition monitoring\rpower generation, storage, and transmission\rnovel wind-turbine designs and optimization\ranalytical, empirical, and numerical modeling\n\t'

title: b'Call for Chapters 2022'
description: b'AI and Machine Learning Applications and Implications in Customer Support and Analytics '
Categories: b'machine learning' b'AI' b'business' b'marketing'
Call For Papers: b'\nCall for Chapters: AI and Machine Learning Applications and Implications in Customer Support and Analytics \r Call for Chapters\rProposals Submission Deadline: August 3, 2022\rFull Chapters Due: December 1, 2022\rSubmission Date: December 1, 2022\r Introduction\rIn the modern data-driven era, artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies that allow a computer to mimic intelligent human behavior are essential for organizations to achieve business excellence and assist organizations in extracting useful information from raw data. For decades, AI and ML have existed, but in the age of big data, this sort of analysis is in higher demand than ever, especially for customer support and analytics. Consequently, this book investigated the applications of AI and ML and how they can be implemented to enhance customer support and analytics at various levels of organizations.\r Objective\rAI and Machine Learning Applications and Implications in Customer Support and Analytics explores various artificial intelligence and machine learning models and methods for business applications, as well as algorithmic approaches for customer support and analytics in a variety of fields and applications in the modern data-driven era where data is arriving in greater variety and with more velocity. This book is ideal for marketing professionals, managers, business owners, researchers, practitioners, academicians, instructors, university libraries, and students, and covers topics such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, supervised learning, unsupervised learning, deep learning, customer sentiment analysis, customer emotional analysis, natural language processing, data mining, neural networks, ensemble learning, business analytics and analytical geared toward.\r Target Audience\rAcademic and business leaders who want to use machine learning and artificial intelligence approaches from data science, machine learning, business intelligence, Big Data, data mining, statistics, and other related disciplines to put the data they\'ve collected into action via insights and prescriptions are the primary target audience for this proposed publication. The topics discussed in the publication will be used by marketing professionals, managers, business owners, researchers, practitioners, academics, instructors, university libraries, and students to develop settings for data-driven decision-making in their respective fields. By evaluating the use of methodologies in the business sector, data scientists will contribute to and learn from the publication. Finally, this book may be considered as a reference book for data science and business analytics courses and training for graduate and postgraduate students at various universities and institutes.\r Recommended Topics\r* Artificial Intelligence * Machine Learning * Business analytics * Business Intelligence * Business Applications * Deep Learning * Using machine learning models to solve business problems * Managing the ML and AI functions in organizations * Customer Engagement * Customer Retention * Informing customer personas with data * Marketing Analytics approaches * Scaling up customer support with AI and ML * Integrating business rules with ML models for prescriptive intelligence\r Submission Procedure\r Researchers and practitioners are invited to submit on or before August 3, 2022, a chapter proposal of 1,000 to 2,000 words clearly explaining the mission and concerns of his or her proposed chapter. Authors will be notified by August 17, 2022 about the status of their proposals and sent chapter guidelines.Full chapters are expected to be submitted by December 1, 2022, and all interested authors must consult the guidelines for manuscript submissions at https://www.igi-global.com/publish/contributor-resources/before-you-write/ prior to submission. All submitted chapters will be reviewed on a double-blind review basis. Contributors may also be requested to serve as reviewers for this project.\r Note: There are no submission or acceptance fees for manuscripts submitted to this book publication, AI and Machine Learning Applications and Implications in Customer Support and Analytics. All manuscripts are accepted based on a double-blind peer review editorial process.\r All proposals should be submitted through the eEditorial Discovery\xc2\xae online submission manager.\r  Publisher\r This book is scheduled to be published by IGI Global (formerly Idea Group Inc.), an international academic publisher of the "Information Science Reference" (formerly Idea Group Reference), "Medical Information Science Reference," "Business Science Reference," and "Engineering Science Reference" imprints. IGI Global specializes in publishing reference books, scholarly journals, and electronic databases featuring academic research on a variety of innovative topic areas including, but not limited to, education, social science, medicine and healthcare, business and management, information science and technology, engineering, public administration, library and information science, media and communication studies, and environmental science. For additional information regarding the publisher, please visit https://www.igi-global.com. This publication is anticipated to be released in 2023.\r  Important Dates\r August 3, 2022: Proposal Submission Deadline\rAugust 17, 2022: Notification of Acceptance\rDecember 1, 2022: Full Chapter Submission\rJanuary 29, 2023: Review Results Returned\rMarch 12, 2023: Final Acceptance Notification\rMarch 26, 2023: Final Chapter Submission\r  Inquiries\r Md Shamim Hossain\rHajee Mohammad Danesh Science and Technology University\rshamimuibe@yahoo.com\r Ree Ho\rTaylor\xe2\x80\x99s University\rreechanho@gmail.com\r Goran Trajkovski\rWestern Governors University\rgoran.trajkovski@wgu.edu\n\t'
