title: b'Black British Women\xe2\x80\x99s Writing, 1970 and  2022'
description: b'Away from Home: Black British Women\xe2\x80\x99s Writing, 1970 and Beyond'
Categories: b'british literature' b'immigrant novel' b'post-colonial literature' b'women writers'
Call For Papers: b'\nAway from Home: Black British Women\xe2\x80\x99s Writing, 1970 and Beyond\r The arrival of the Empire Windrush at Tilbury on 22 June 1948 marked the beginning of an important period in British writing but also an era that largely silenced women writers\xe2\x80\x94particularly women writers of colour. In the years following the arrival of the Windrush, the output of women writers of colour in the UK, or Black British women writers, increased. Yet, recognition of this group was not as forthcoming as acclaim and acknowledgement rested largely on male writers. While the work of all immigrant writers in the UK\xe2\x80\x94particularly those texts that recount the lived experiences surrounding immigration\xe2\x80\x94is critical to literature studies, women writers have historically been isolated to the margins of the canon. Specifically, immigrant women writers in the UK in the post-Windrush years, with a few exceptions, seem to labour almost in silence. This collection proposes an examination of Black British women\xe2\x80\x99s writing, focusing on the years after 1970, addressing the female immigrant experience. Some authors of interest are Eintou Pearl Springer (Trinidad), Binta Breeze (Jamaica), June Henfrey (Barbados), Buchi Emecheta (Nigeria), Hannah Pool (Eritrea), Nadifa Mohamed (Somalia), and Irenosen Okojie (Nigeria). Essays addressing the work of women writers who are British born, second generation, such as Bernadine Evaristo, Patience Agbabi, Monica Ali, and Meera Syal, are also welcome.\r Some topics include, but are not limited to:\r \xe2\x80\xa2\tPost Windrush female immigrants in British society\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tBlack British female bildungsroman\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tBlack British female immigrants and the Welfare State\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tImmigration and motherhood\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tMarriage and family structure in a diaspora\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tHealthcare, NHIS, and immigrants\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tImmigrant employment opportunities (or lack thereof)\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tImmigration and education\r NB: This collection is under contract with Cambridge Scholars Publishing.\r Final Submission Requirements:\r Final essays should be between 5000-7000 words, follow Chicago Manual of Style, utilise British English spelling, scholarly based, and free of copyright restrictions (statement of support required).\r All chapters submitted should conform to the grammar and formatting guidelines provided by Cambridge Scholars Publishing, which can be viewed here: https://www.cambridgescholars.com/pages/forms-guidelines; \r Due dates are as follows:\r 300-word abstracts & 50-word author biography\t                September 1\rResponse\t\t\t\t\t\t\tSeptember 20\rFirst draft\t\t\t\t\t\t\tNovember 30\rFeedback\t\t\t\t\t\t\tDecember 30\rFinal draft\t\t\t\t\t\t\tFebruary 15\r Please submit all inquiries and documents to calexander@tuskegee.edu.\r\n'

title: b'XR-SPro 2022'
description: b'Workshop on XR Solutions for Smart Production'
Categories: b'augmented reality' b'mixed reality' b'smart production' b'virtual reality'
Call For Papers: b'\nWorkshop on XR Solutions for Smart Production (XR-SPro-2022)\r17.10.2022 in Singapore, in conjunction with ISMAR 2022 (held physically on site in Singapore)\rhttps://www.xr-spro.net\r ==Description==\rJust like the industrial revolutions before it, smart production (also known as Industry 4.0) is going to increase the ability of workers to create high-quality products and improve the customer experience. However, unlike earlier developments, smart production will allow for high levels of automation, customization, productivity, and efficiency that have never been seen before. Within these "smart factories" all processes interoperate seamlessly based on big data. And as the complexity of the processes increases, the demands placed on the work to be performed increase significantly.\rAugmented, virtual and mixed reality technologies offer a wide range of capabilities to support workers in future factories and present information in more interactive ways than their two-dimensional counterparts. XR assistance systems promise to increase the workers\xe2\x80\x99 efficiency by providing the right information at the right moment. If well implemented, XR can provide valuable assistance in increasingly complexity production environments.\rAgainst this background, an increasing impact of production processes supported by XR systems is to be expected within the next years. XR will facilitate work processes and individualize the information required by employees, which is important in times of skill shortages, travel restrictions and social distancing, thus enabling less qualified employees to work in more highly qualified jobs. XR also provides assistance for the higher-skilled to support problem-solving tasks, networking, and documentation of experience. The optimization information visualization, product quality, and processes contributes to securing sustainable safeguarding of manufacturing locations and to creating attractive jobs. However, the implementation of XR applications in manufacturing needs a high user acceptance, which is important for the actual use of the technology in work processes.\rConnecting specialists from various related research areas (such as automation systems engineering, production planning, etc.), with experts from both vision-oriented computer science areas (such as computer graphics or information visualization), and experts from XR-oriented computer science areas, the XR-SPro workshop series aims to create an open environment for discussing and investigating novel XR solutions for smart production. This includes (among others) the usage of spatial computing approaches for real-time data visualization, XR-supported remote assistance and customizable training scenarios that mimic reality and let workers train from anywhere at their own pace. By encouraging synergies of interdisciplinary approaches, the workshop tackles different applications of XR in a smart production context from different angles and creates new knowledge in this research field. XR-SPro wants to account to the state-of-the-art research in smart production with different XR applications, to shape a common understanding, to compare systems and approaches and derive common paradigms, to develop useful and necessary methods and techniques, and to foster new ideas.\r Topics of interest include (but are not limited to):\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tUse Cases and pilot applications\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tXR-supported remote assistance\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tXR training and onboarding scenarios\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tSpatial computing in industry\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tHardware/Software support for smart production applications of XR\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tGamified XR environments in industry\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tInterdisciplinary and intermedia approaches\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tUser Acceptance of smart production XR applications\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tReal-time XR visualization of sensor and process data\r\xe2\x97\x8f\tTactility and physicality of XR applications in smart production\r ==Deadlines & Dates==\rPaper Submission Deadline: July 4, 2022\rNotification of acceptance: August 8, 2022\rCamera-ready Deadline: August 29, 2022\rWorkshop day: October 17, 2022\r ==Contribution Formats==\rFollowing the last years, contributions are planned to be included and indexed in the IEEE digital library.\r1.\tResearch Papers (6-8 pages) Novel results in the field in the above-mentioned categories related to XR development.\r2.\tShort Papers (up to 4 pages) Preliminary results or work in progress.\r3.\tState of the Art Reports (6-8 pages) Surveys on the main results in this field, which will allow us to understand and compare achievements and approaches in tackling issues from the XR communities.\r Papers must be written in English and follow the IEEE Computer Society VGTC format for described at: https://tc.computer.org/vgtc/publications/conference/\r All papers and camera-ready versions have to be submitted electronically using the conference management tool found at the website: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=xrspro2022\r Submissions will be reviewed by at least 2 program committee members following a single-blind review process. Accepted papers will be given guidelines in preparing and submitting the final manuscript(s) together with the notification of acceptance.\r ==Workshop Format==\rThe XR-SPro workshop will be a half-day event held physically in Singapore. Accepted authors for state of the art descriptions and discussion essays will present their ideas in a panel-like format. Accepted contributions for research papers will be organized in sessions consisting of presentations and discussions.\r During panels, we will encourage the active participation of the audience. We expect this structure to provide a more focused discussions and a lively environment. Presenters will be asked to prepare a slide presentation of their accepted contribution. The general audience of this workshop will receive the workshop\xc2\xb4s program with a set of questions in advance, which will guide the discussion in each topic\xc2\xb4s panel.\r ==Organizers==\rThomas Moser (St. P\xc3\xb6lten University of Applied Sciences), thomas.moser@fhstp.ac.at\rJosef Wolfartsberger (University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria), josef.wolfartsberger@fh-ooe.at\r \n'

title: b'CIFS 2022'
description: b'4th International Workshop on Cloud, IoT and Fog Systems (and Security)'
Categories: b'IOT' b'FOG' b'cloud' b'security'
Call For Papers: b'\n4th International Workshop on Cloud, IoT and Fog Systems (and Security)\r Co-located with the 15th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing \xe2\x80\x94 UCC 2022Portland, Oregon, USA, December 6--9, 2022\r Description\r Highly sophisticated compute networks, encompassing small networked sensors and hyperscaler clouds, are becoming a mainstream technology concern. The density of sensing increases, as does the frequency and amount of data generation. Monolithic big data frameworks do not fit well into this scheme and moreover do not reflect well the distinct operational models and responsibilities due to conventional handling of credentials. At the same time, developer-accessible cloud DevOps frameworks are increasingly becoming a choice to run at edge nodes, leading to diverse IoT-edge/fog-cloud continuum models for programming and deployment.\r The CIFS workshop gathers researchers and innovators around the challenges of building and operating complex computing topologies and associated cloud architectures around the Internet of Things and Cyber-Physical Systems, bridging the digital world with our environment. It calls for research and experience reports, from the algorithm level to completed production systems, in order to advance the knowledge resulting from progress in overcoming the challenges. CIFS also welcomes data-centric studies, simulations, testbeds and similar helpful software solutions.\r This year, in the face of the increasing complexity and massive scale of things-to-cloud applications and deployments in the real world, CIFS particularly welcomes submissions focused on the cloud-native security and resilience aspects of such applications.\r Topics of Interest\r We solicit research papers (up to 6p) and technical industry reports (typically 3-6p) on the following topics:\r     IoT-fog-cloud pipelines, architectures and continuums in various domains, from industrial deployments to smart cities\r    Smartness, adaptivity, fluidity and dynamicity for processing sensed data\r    Computing paradigms: multi-cloud, fog, serverless, osmotic, continuum computing\r    Applications in digitalised health care, ecology, agriculture, urban planning and other fields\r    Secure cloud/fog computing concepts (homomorphic encryption, enclaves, hardware security modules, stealth computing, coded computing among others)\r    Long-term distributed messaging and data storage security and proof-of-ownership/provision/retrievability\r    End-to-end reliability and security concepts across IoT-fog-cloud continuums\r    Physical and digital security of IoT deployments, smart meters and other end devices\r    Privacy, scalability and economics considerations as well as trade-offs\r    Cross-border, cross-provider and cross-stack security issues\r    Human factors: simplicity and controllability of complex CPS and CPSoS\r    Security, identity management and multitenancy in clouds and continuums\r Submission Information\r Submitted papers should contain results or reports not already published or submitted elsewhere, in IEEE format. All papers will be peer-reviewed by at least three programme committee members. The evaluation will be based on originality, relevance of the problem to the workshop topics, technical strength, quality of results, and clarity of the presentation. The publication of the workshop proceeding with all accepted papers will be by the IEEE and will appear in the same or companion volume as the UCC 2022 and BDCAT 2022 conferences. At least one author of each accepted submission must register in full and attend the workshop to present and all workshop participants must pay the IEEE conference or workshop registration fee.\r Submission page: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=cifs2022\r Important Dates\r     Submission September 03, 2022\r    Notification October 01, 2022\r    Camera-ready October 15, 2022\r All deadlines are indicated as AOE - Anywhere On Earth.\r Workshop Organisers\r     Panagiotis Gkikopoulos, Zurich University of Applied Sciences, Switzerland\r    Cristina Abad, ESPOL, Ecuador\r    Florian Forster, CEO and co-founder, Zitadel, Switzerland\r\n'

title: b'PIES-ME 2022'
description: b'The 1st Workshop on Photorealistic Image and Environment Synthesis for Multimedia Experiments (PIES-ME)'
Categories: b'multimedia' b'networking' b'image processing' b'computer science'
Call For Papers: b"\nCALL FOR PAPERS\r The 1st Workshop on Photorealistic Image and Environment Synthesis for Multimedia Experiments (PIES-ME)\r Lisbon, Portugal\rOctober 10-14, 2022\r http://www2.ene.unb.br/2022-pies-me/\r Co-located with ACM Multimedia 2022\rhttps://2022.acmmm.org/\r IMPORTANT DATES\r Paper Submission: July 22, 2022\rNotification of Acceptance: August 7, 2022\rCamera-ready version: August 21, 2022\r INTRODUCTION\r Photorealistic media aim to faithfully represent the world, creating an experience which is perceptually indistinguishable from a real world experience. Current standard media applications fall short of this goal since acquisition and production technologies in the consumer applications do not capture/produce enough of the world\xe2\x80\x99s visual, audio, spatial, and temporal information to faithfully represent it. In the last years, however, the area of photorealistic media has seen a lot of activity, with new multimedia areas emerging, such as light fields, point clouds, ultra-high definition, high frame rate, high dynamic range imaging, and novel 3D audio and sound field technologies. The combination of these technologies can certainly contribute to pave the way for hyper-realistic media experience. But first, we have to overcome several technological challenges. It is worth pointing out that research in this area requires the use of big datasets, software tools, and powerful infrastructures. Among these, the availability of meaningful datasets, with a diverse and high-quality content, is of significant importance.\r The goal of this workshop is to engage experts and researchers on the synthesis of photorealistic images and/or virtual environments, particularly in the form of public datasets, software tools, or infrastructures, for multimedia research. Such public datasets, software tools, and infrastructures will lower entry barriers by enabling researchers that lack expensive hardware (e.g., complex camera systems, smart glasses, robots, autonomous vehicles) to simulate and create datasets representative of such hardware and various scenarios. Photorealistic image and environment synthesis can benefit multiple research areas in addition to multimedia systems, such as machine learning, robotics, computer vision, mixed reality, and virtual reality.\r TOPICS OF INTEREST\r We welcome novel and unpublished research contributions on the following topics (but not limited to):\r - Characteristics of indoor and outdoor environments for multimedia research\r- Hardware and software tools for generation/alteration/customization of photorealistic virtual environments\r- Camera motion and video editing techniques\r- Standardization of video resolution and content for dataset comparison and aggregation\r- Objective and subjective QoE metrics for multimedia streaming and consumption\r- Standardized human subjects\xe2\x80\x99 data collection in multimedia streaming experiments\r- Dataset curation and dissemination platforms and tools\r WORKSHOP CHAIRS\r Ravi Prakash, University of Texas at Dallas, USA\rMylene Farias. University of Bras\xc3\xadlia, Brazil\rRyan P. McMahan. University of Central Florida, USA\rMarcelo M. Carvalho. University of Bras\xc3\xadlia, Brazil\r TECHNICAL PROGRAM COMMITTEE\r Federica Battisti, University of Padova, Italy\rMarco Carli, Universit\xc3\xa0 degli Studi Roma TRE, Italy\rJiasi Chen, University of California Riverside, USA\rAladine Chetouani, Universit\xc3\xa9 d'Orl\xc3\xa9ans, France\rFrederic Dufaux, CNRS, Centrale Supelec, Universit\xc3\xa9 Paris-Saclay, France\rJes\xc3\xbas Guti\xc3\xa9rrez, Universidad Polit\xc3\xa9cnica de Madrid, Spain\rChaker Larabi, Universit\xc3\xa9 de Poitiers, France\rPramit Mazumdar, Indian Institute of Information Technology Vadodara (IIIT-V), India\rLaura Toni, University College London, UK\rGiuseppe Valenzise, CNRS, CentraleSupelec, Universit\xc3\xa9 Paris-Saclay, France\rToinon Vigier, Universit\xc3\xa9 de Nantes, France\rZhisheng Yan, George Mason University, USA\rMichael Zink, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, USA\r WEB CHAIRS\r Henrique D. Garcia, University of Bras\xc3\xadlia, Brazil\rGabriel C. Ara\xc3\xbajo, University of Bras\xc3\xadlia, Brazil\r PAPER SUBMISSION\r Authors are invited to submit original, unpublished research papers that are not currently under review elsewhere. All submissions should be written in English limited to six (6) pages of content, including all figures, tables, and references, plus up to one (1) page of reference in PDF format. Authors must use the ACM Article Template. Please use the template in traditional double-column format to prepare your submissions. The word users may use Word Interim Template, and latex users may use sample-sigconf template. All submissions will undergo blind review. \n\t"

title: b'KM4LAW 2022'
description: b'KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT FOR LAW'
Categories: b'legal studies' b'artificial intelligence' b'knowledge modeling' b'information extraction'
Call For Papers: b'\nKNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT FOR LAW\r Co-located with the 23rd International Conference on Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management (EKAW 2022)\r WORKSHOP AIM AND SCOPE\r Artificial Intelligence (AI), Knowledge Modeling (KM) and Information Extraction (IE) methods are increasingly important for many sub-domains of legal informatics, including ontologies, argumentation, natural language processing, and network analysis, eventually paired with a multilingual approach. The Knowledge Management for Law (KM4LAW) workshop intends to be a forum to focus on legal informatics from different perspectives.\rThe advanced developments in AI over recent years have meant that seemingly insurmountable problems in AI & Law are beginning to be addressed. Accordingly, it is necessary to identify the limits of automated systems and how such systems can handle the remaining unsolved intentional and unintentional ambiguities and conflicts that require legal interpretation. Therefore, research works on the limits and unexplored opportunities offered by AI for the representation of knowledge in the legal domain constitute worthwhile contributions for this workshop.\rTypical goals may include: classification of legal sources, legal design and legal ontologies, similarity among legal decisions and clustering, prediction and support during judicial decision making, legal interpretation support, identification of evolution of legal concepts and definitions over time, information extraction and classification, detection of linguistic phenomena and patterns in legal sources, multilingual alignments of concepts on domestic and international legal sources, identification of legal references and network analysis, analogical reasoning, and compliance checking.\r TOPICS OF INTEREST\r The workshop will look for original, high quality contributions that explore the following (non-exhaustive) list of topics:\r- Natural language processing techniques and systems for legal documents\r- Identification of legal semantic roles and extraction of named entities\r- Automated knowledge extraction from legal text corpora\r- Experimental results using and adapting NLP methods for legal data\r- Information retrieval and multimedia search for legal documents\r- Multilingual alignments, retrieval, extraction and analysis of legal sources\r- Linked data and knowledge graphs in the legal domain\r- Classification or clustering of law\r- Domain-Specific Visual Modeling Language (DSVML) and law\r- Legal ontologies, visual law, legal design, and correlated themes\r- (Multilingual) Thesauri, vocabularies, and taxonomies in the legal area\r- Entity Recognition and Disambiguation\r- Training and Using Embeddings for legal text\r- Computational models of argumentation for legal data\r- Knowledge Base Population\r- Question Answering, Dialogue and Discourse Analysis, Query Understanding\r- Link Analysis, Relation and Event Extraction\r- Combining Legal Text with Structured Data\r- Legal Text Summarization and Generation\r- Emerging applications in legal data & knowledge engineering\r SUBMISSION INSTRUCTIONS\r Authors are invited to submit original, previously unpublished research papers.\r Papers should be written in English, following the new CEUR-ART 1-column style.\rThe LaTeX files for the new CEURART style are available as Overleaf Template: https://www.overleaf.com/latex/templates/template-for-submissions-to-ceur-workshop-proceedings-ceur-ws-dot-org/hpvjjzhjxzjk\rTo download an offline version with the style files: http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-XXX/CEURART.zip (it also contains DOCX template files)\r All papers must be converted to PDF prior to electronic submission.\r We accept two kinds of contributions:\r- short paper must be between 5 to 9 pages long (excluding references)\r- regular paper must be at least 10 pages long (excluding references)\rAt least one author of each accepted paper must register and participate in the workshop.\r According to CEUR-WS policy, the papers will be published under a CC BY 4.0 license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en) that will be included in an open-access post-proceedings volume of CEUR Workshop Proceedings (http://ceur-ws.org/), indexed by both Scopus and DBLP.\r We are planning a Journal Special Issue, we will provide new information shortly.\r Submissions should be made via the Easychair system through the following submission page: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=km4law\r WORKSHOP ORGANIZERS (in alphabetical order)\r Davide Audrito, University of Bologna (Italy)\rLuigi Di Caro,  University of Turin (Italy)\rFrancesca Grasso, University of Turin (Italy)\rRoberto Nai, University of Turin (Italy)\rEmilio Sulis, University of Turin (Italy)\r PROGRAM COMMITTEE\r Kolawole ADEBAYO (Dublin City University, Ireland / ADAPT Centre, Ireland)\rValerio BASILE (University of Turin, Italy)\rGuido BOELLA (University of Turin, Italy)\rBeatriz ESTEVES (Universidad Polit\xc3\xa9cnica de Madrid, Spain)\rAlfio FERRARA (University of Milan, Italy)\rStefano MONTANELLI (University of Milan, Italy)\rRohan NANDA (University of Maastricht, Netherlands)\rMar\xc3\xada NAVAS LORO (Universidad Polit\xc3\xa9cnica de Madrid, Spain)\rMonica PALMIRANI (University of Bologna, Italy)\rHarshvardhan J. PANDIT (Trinity College, Dublin)\rLivio ROBALDO (Swansea University, Wales)\rV\xc3\xadctor RODR\xc3\x8dGUEZ-DONCEL (Universidad Polit\xc3\xa9cnica de Madrid, Spain)\rSalvatore SAPIENZA (University of Bologna, Italy)\rGalileo SARTOR (University of Bologna, Italy)\rGiovanni SIRAGUSA (University of Turin, Italy)\rAndrea TAGARELLI (University of Calabria, Italy)\r\n'

title: b'WoSC 2022'
description: b'Eighth International Workshop on Serverless Computing (WoSC8) 2022'
locality: b'Virtual and Fairmont Le Ch\xc3\xa2teau Frontena'
Categories: b'serverless' b'cloud' b'computing' b'hybrid'
Call For Papers: b"\nEighth International Workshop on Serverless Computing (WoSC8)\r    Part of [1]ACM/IFIP Middleware 2022.\r    WoSC8 will be hybrid this year with both virtual and on-location\r   formats. Please note that while hybrid formats will be supported for\r   workshops, the Middleware \xe2\x80\x9922 steering committee wants the main\r   conference to be held in in-person only. Prospective attendees of the\r   workshop should keep this in mind if they plan to attend both WoSC8 and\r   Middleware \xe2\x80\x9822.\r    Over the last seven years, Serverless Computing (Serverless) has gained\r   an enthusiastic following in industry as a compelling paradigm for the\r   deployment of cloud applications, and is enabled by the recent shift of\r   enterprise application architectures to containers and microservices.\r   Many of the major cloud vendors have released serverless platforms,\r   including Amazon Lambda, Google Cloud Functions, Microsoft Azure\r   Functions, IBM Cloud Functions. Open source projects are gaining\r   popularity in providing serverless computing as a service.\r    Recently, Kubernetes gained popularity in enterprise and in academia.\r   Several open source projects such as OpenFaaS and Knative aim to\r   provide developers with serverless experience on top of Kubernetes by\r   hiding low-level details. Auto-scalable multi-tenant Kubernetes\r   deployments like Google Cloud Run or IBM Code Engine also overcome\r   previous limitations of Serverless Functions like duration, networking,\r   and higher granularity (more vCPUs).\r    Serverless architectures offer different tradeoffs in terms of control,\r   cost, and flexibility compared to distributed applications built on an\r   Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) substrate. For example, a serverless\r   architecture requires developers to more carefully consider the\r   resources used by their code (time to execute, memory used, etc.) when\r   modularizing their applications. This is in contrast to concerns around\r   latency, scalability, and elasticity, which is where significant\r   development effort has traditionally been spent when building cloud\r   services. In addition, tools and techniques to monitor and debug\r   applications aren't applicable in serverless architectures, and new\r   approaches are needed. As well, test and development pipelines may need\r   to be adapted. Another decision that developers face is the\r   appropriateness of the serverless ecosystem to their application\r   requirements. A rich ecosystem of services built into the platform is\r   typically easier to compose and would offer better performance.\r   However, composing external services may be unavoidable, and in such\r   cases, many of the benefits of serverless disappear, including\r   performance and availability guarantees. This presents an important\r   research challenge, and it is not clear how existing results and best\r   practices, such as workflow composition research, can be applied to\r   composition in a serverless environment.\r    As this year the workshop is virtual and we are looking not only for\r   research papers, experience papers, demonstrations, or position papers\r   but also for live presentations of ongoing work, demonstrations, and\r   anything else that may be interesting to workshop audience.\r    The latest version of this CFP is available at\r   [2]http://serverlesscomputing.org/wosc8/\r Topics\r    This workshop solicits papers from both academia and industry on the\r   state of practice and state of the art in serverless computing. Topics\r   of interest include but are not limited to:\r     * Infrastructure and network optimizations for serverless\r       applications\r     * Debugging serverless applications\r     * Programming models\r     * Use cases, experiences\r     * Benchmarks\r     * Cost models, pricing models, and economics of serverless\r     * DevOps\r     * Other topics related to serverless computing\r Important Dates\r    Paper Submission: August 31, 2022\r   Notification of Acceptance: September 23, 2022\r   Final Camera-Ready Manuscript (Hard Deadline): October 3, 2022\r   Non-paper submissions (demos and other proposals): November 10, 2022\r   Author registration deadline: TBD\r   Conference: November 7-11, 2022\r Papers and Submissions\r Papers submissions\r    Authors are invited to submit original, unpublished\r   research/application papers that are not being considered in another\r   forum.\r    Submitted manuscripts should be structured as technical papers and may\r   not exceed six (6) single-spaced double-column pages using ACM SIGPLAN\r   style, which can be found on the ACM template page. The page limit\r   contains all the content, including bibliography, appendix, etc.\r    Submitted papers must adhere to the formatting instructions of the ACM\r   SIGPLAN style, which can be found on the [3]ACM template page. The font\r   size has to be set to 10pt.\r    Note that submissions must be double-blind: authors\xe2\x80\x99 names must not\r   appear, and authors must make a good faith attempt to anonymize their\r   submissions.\r    The Middleware conference organizers will provide companion proceedings\r   including all workshop papers, which will be available in the ACM\r   Digital Library. This is subject to the availability of their\r   camera-ready papers by October 10, 2021.\r    Authors should submit the manuscript in PDF format. All manuscripts\r   will be reviewed and will be judged on correctness, originality,\r   technical strength, rigour in analysis, quality of results, quality of\r   presentation, and interest and relevance to the conference attendees.\r   Papers conforming to the above guidelines can be submitted through the\r   paper submission system powered by HotCRP\r   ([4]https://wosc8.hotcrp.com/).\r    All submitted manuscripts (following MIDDLEWARE conference requirements\r   on formatting and page limits) will be peer-reviewed by at least 3\r   program committee members. Accepted papers with confirmed presentation\r   will appear in the conference proceedings as well as in the ACM Digital\r   Library.\r Other submissions\r    Authors are invited to submit proposals for demos and other\r   presentations that are not papers.\r    Proposals must be submitted as short abstracts (not longer than one\r   page) in PDF format using the paper submission system HotCRP\r   ([5]https://wosc8.hotcrp.com/).\r    Accepted presentations will not be part of the conference proceedings\r   but will be part of the workshop agenda with dedicated time for live\r   presentation (with video backup), questions etc.\r Workshop co-chairs\r    Paul Castro, IBM Research\r   Pedro Garc\xc3\xada L\xc3\xb3pez, University Rovira i Virgili\r   Vatche Ishakian, IBM Research\r   Vinod Muthusamy, IBM Research\r   Aleksander Slominski, IBM Research\r Steering Committee\r    Geoffrey Fox, Indiana University\r   Dennis Gannon, Indiana University & Formerly Microsoft Research\r   Arno Jacobsen, MSRG (Middleware Systems Research Group)\r Program Committee (tentative)\r    Gul Agha, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign\r   Azer Bestavros, Boston University\r   Tyler R. title: b'FATESys 2022'
description: b'Second ACM SIGEnergy Workshop on Fair, Accountable, Transparent, and Ethical (FATE) AI for Smart Environments and Energy Systems'
Categories: b'fairness' b'interpretability' b'AI/ML' b'built environments'
Call For Papers: b'\nWith the advent of IoT, high performance computing, and ubiquitous and smart sensing, the SenSys/BuildSys community is noticing a big shift in the adoption of data-driven black-box modeling (also referred to as AI) to solve problems in the space of smart environments and energy systems. As a result, these AI-enabled systems for smart buildings, smart cities, smart grids, electric transportation, among others are attaining better accuracy and efficiency numbers every year. However, these data-driven black-box solutions are rarely held accountable for the impact of their actions on the human in the loop which significantly impacts their real-world adoption. To truly conceptualize the idea of smart systems for everyone, it is critical to study AI-enabled smart environments and energy systems to enforce energy equity and ensure not just clean and resilient energy systems, but also make them affordable and accessible for all. The second ACM SIGEnergy workshop on Fair, Accountable, Transparent, and Ethical AI for Smart Environments and Energy Systems intends to bring together researchers from diverse backgrounds and discuss key issues, challenges, breakthroughs, and socio-economic impact in developing fair, accountable, transparent and ethical AI techniques for smart environments and energy systems.\r The aim of this workshop is to create a platform for the SenSys/BuildSys community to discuss developing AI-enabled smart environments and energy systems that are not just accurate but also take responsibility for their actions. We invite submissions including, but not limited to:\r - Studies exploring type of biases in energy-related data and their implications\r- Challenges in collecting representative data for fair training of the AI models\r- Studies on eXplainable AI (XAI) for smart environments and energy systems\r- Interpretable and explainable ML/AI models\r- Physics-informed ML for model interpretation\r- Innovative ML/AI models and their key limitations pertaining to FATE\r- Socio-economic impact analysis for energy equity\r- Fair metrics for the evaluation of ML/AI methods\r- Exploring visual analytics for bias evaluation in data and models\r\n'

title: b'AIMLSystems 2022'
description: b'SECOND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON AI-ML SYSTEMS'
Categories: b'systems for ai/ml' b'ai/ml for systems' b'ai/ml for socio-economic syste'
Call For Papers: b'\nAIMLSystems is a new conference targeting research at the intersection of AI/ML techniques and systems engineering. Through this conference, we plan to bring out and highlight the natural connections between these two fields and their application to socio-economic systems. Specifically, we explore how immense strides in AI/ML techniques are made possible through computational systems research (e.g., improvements in CPU/GPU architectures, data-intensive infrastructure, and communications ), and how the use of AI/ML can help in the continuous and workload-driven design space exploration of computational systems (e.g., self-tuning databases, learning compiler optimisers, and learnable network systems), and the use of AI/ML in the design of socio-economic systems such as public healthcare, and security. The goal is to bring together these diverse communities and elicit connections between them.\r \n'

Call For Papers: b'\n2023 IEEE World Engineering Education Conference (EDUNINE2023) Call for Papers.\rEXTENDED SUBMISSION DEADLINE: SEPTEMBER 19, 2022,\rHybrid Conference (on-site and online)\rSun, March 12, 2023 \xe2\x80\x93 Wed, March 15, 2023\rBogot\xc3\xa1, Colombia (Universidad Central and Universidad del Rosario)\r Website: https://edunine.eu/edunine2023\rCall for papers: https://edunine.eu/edunine2023/cfp/EDUNINE2023cfp.pdf\r Reimaging Engineering - Toward the next generation of Engineering Education, merging technologies in a connected world\r NEW Important Dates\r 19 September 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Full, WIP or Workshop Paper Submission\r28 October 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Acceptance Notification\r30 November 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Final Paper Submission and Early Registration\r3 March 2023 \xe2\x80\x93 Late Registration\r 2023 IEEE World Engineering Education Conference invites authors to submit original research in English in the form of full papers (up to six pages) and work-in-progress papers (up to four pages) that address the main conference theme and the conference prevalent topics. In addition, EDUNINE 2023 welcomes proposals for workshops to promote lifelong learning for educators. Workshops are single and short (from 90 minutes to a full day) educational programs designed to provide participants with practical skills, techniques, or ideas that they can use in their work.\rEDUNINE 2023, as a conference in the field of engineering and technology education, has enriched the scientific community with its quality and opportunity to promote communication between academics and researchers. With participants from all over the world, university academics and young researchers had the opportunity to network and exchange useful knowledge. This is another important contribution to the development and dissemination of scientific achievements for human development, to building bridges between communities, and helping educators and policymakers find creative and innovative solutions for teaching and learning in the current crisis and in the longer-term future.\rEDUNINE 2023 will be held as a hybrid conference with combined online and on-site presentations. This conference will be a seamless integration of technology to facilitate participation between a live and virtual audience.  Authors can choose to present their papers in English, Portuguese, or Spanish on-site at the conference venues (Universidad Central and Universidad del Rosario in Bogota) or online only through the online platform. Both forms of presentation are of equal value. Accepted and presented papers will be submitted for inclusion in the IEEE Xplore\xc2\xae digital library. IEEE has agreements with other publishers and services such as Google, Elsevier (Scopus, ScienceDirect, and Compendex), Web of Science, Ei Engineering Village, and Scitopia.org.\rFor more information and the full list of topics, please visit the conference website: https://edunine.eu/edunine2023  (in English, Portuguese, and Spanish). \rFor questions, please contact edunine@edunine.eu\r\n'

title: b'NLP_ML_DS 2022'
description: b'Advanced Applications of NLP and Deep Learning in Social Media Data '
Categories: b'NLP' b'deep/machine learning' b'data science' b'text mining'
Call For Papers: b'\nIntroduction:\r\xf0\x9d\x90\x8d\xf0\x9d\x90\x9a\xf0\x9d\x90\xad\xf0\x9d\x90\xae\xf0\x9d\x90\xab\xf0\x9d\x90\x9a\xf0\x9d\x90\xa5 \xf0\x9d\x90\x8b\xf0\x9d\x90\x9a\xf0\x9d\x90\xa7\xf0\x9d\x90\xa0\xf0\x9d\x90\xae\xf0\x9d\x90\x9a\xf0\x9d\x90\xa0\xf0\x9d\x90\x9e \xf0\x9d\x90\x8f\xf0\x9d\x90\xab\xf0\x9d\x90\xa8\xf0\x9d\x90\x9c\xf0\x9d\x90\x9e\xf0\x9d\x90\xac\xf0\x9d\x90\xac\xf0\x9d\x90\xa2\xf0\x9d\x90\xa7\xf0\x9d\x90\xa0 (\xf0\x9d\x90\x8d\xf0\x9d\x90\x8b\xf0\x9d\x90\x8f) makes machines able to analyze, understand and interpret human languages. NLP resides at the core of our everyday tools\xe2\x80\x93 from the Siri assistant in apple products, translation software, chatbots, spam filters, and search engines, to language correction software, and social media monitoring tools. NLP by combining the knowledge of linguistics and the powerful computer science AI, comprehend the rules and structure of language and creates intelligent systems to understand, analyze, and extract meaning from text and speech. NLP analyzes the different aspects like syntax, semantics, pragmatics, and morphology to understand the structure and meaning of the human text. Then, the power computers can transform this linguistic knowledge into Advanced Machine Learning (AML) algorithms that can solve specific problems and perform desired tasks. Machine Learning and NLP play a crucial role in converting an artificial system into an artificially intelligent system. An Artificially Intelligent system can accept better information in a user-friendly manner by utilizing the power of NLP and processes the received information with ML techniques to perform better predictions. Social media platforms are one of the main generators of textual data where people around the world share their daily life experiences and information with the online society. The social, personal, and professional lives of people on these social networking sites generate not only a huge amount of data but also open doors for researchers and academicians with ample research opportunities. This ample amount of data heterogeneous data needs advanced ML, DL, and intelligent tools and techniques to receive, process, and interpret the information in order to resolve several real-life challenges and make the online social life of people harmless and better. Each chapter in this book will contribute to the technology and methodology perspective to incorporate advanced NLP and Deep learning approaches in collecting, analyzing, visualizing, and processing the social data to solve a wide range of real-life issues. Furthermore, this book will present state-of-the-art research and empirical studies on the role of NLP and DL in social media data.\r Topics to be covered by the Book (but not limited to):\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tNatural Language Processing (NLP): Introduction, Methods, Issues, and Challenges. \r\xe2\x80\xa2\tNatural Language Processing for Online Social Media: Sentiment, Semantic Aspect, Toxicity, and Emotion Analysis.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tRole of Machine/Deep Learning in building prediction systems for Online Social Media platforms.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tIntelligent Artificial systems for Online Social Media.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tStance, Fake, and Toxic News detection systems using Deep NLP techniques.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tInfluential, core node and propaganda identification in Online Social Networks.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tTopic Modeling, Named Entity Recognition (NET), and Hate Speech Detection using NLP and Deep Machine Models\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tOpinion Mining and fake review/comment classification using social media data.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tFake profile, Honey nodes, and Sexual Predator Detection in Online Social Networks.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tTrolling, Cyber-stalking, Cyber-bullying, Identity theft in OSNs: Methods, Issues, and Challenges.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tProtecting, Personal, Social, and Professional Information on Social Media.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tMental health (Depression, Suicidal ideation, mood swing) Prediction and Detection using Online Social Media data.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tUser Behavioral Analysis using Behavioral biometric and digital footprints.\r\xe2\x80\xa2\tData Collection (Scrappers, Crawlers, and APIs), Preprocessing, Annotation and Evaluation Techniques: Challenges and Issues.\r Submission Procedure:\r Researchers and practitioners are invited to submit on or before July 6, 2022, a chapter proposal of 1,000 to 2,000 words clearly explaining the mission and concerns of the proposed chapter. Authors will be notified by July 20, 2022, about the status of their proposals and sent chapter guidelines. Full chapters are expected to be submitted by September 18, 2022, and all interested authors must consult the guidelines for manuscript submissions at https://www.igi-global.com/publish/contributor-resources/before-you-write/ prior to submission. All submitted chapters will be reviewed on a double-blind review basis. Contributors may also be requested to serve as reviewers for this project.\r  Prospective authors should send their manuscripts electronically through the IGI link:\rhttps://www.igi-global.com/publish/call-for-papers/submit/6000\r Contact:\rIn case of questions, please feel free to contact the editors:\r Ahmed Abd El-Latif (aabdellatif@psu.edu.sa)\rMudasir Ahmad Wani (mwani@psu.edu.sa)\rMohammed ELAffendi (affendi@psu.edu.sa)\r\n'

title: b'CoCo4MT 2022'
description: b'2nd CFP - The First Workshop on Corpus Generation and Corpus Augmentation for Machine Translation'
Categories: b'NLP' b'artificial intelligence' b'computer science' b'machine learning'
Call For Papers: b'\nCoCo4MT 2nd CFP - The First Workshop on Corpus Generation and Corpus Augmentation for Machine Translation\r  The First Workshop on Corpus Generation and Corpus Augmentation for Machine Translation (CoCo4MT)\rhttps://sites.google.com/view/coco4mt\r@ AMTA \xe2\x80\x93 2022\rThis 15th biennial conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas \r12-16 September 2022, Orlando, Florida, USA\r INVITED TALKS\r Julia Kreutzer Google Research\rMore TBA...\r SCOPE\r It is a well-known fact that machine translation systems, especially those that use deep learning, require massive amounts of data. Several resources for languages are not available in their human-created format. Some of the types of resources available are monolingual, multilingual, translation memories, and lexicons. Those types of resources are generally created for formal purposes such as parliamentary collections when parallel and more informal situations when monolingual. The quality and abundance of resources including corpora used for formal reasons is generally higher than those used for informal purposes. Additionally, corpora for low-resource languages, languages with less digital resources available, tends to be less abundant and of lower quality.\r CoCo4MT sets out to be the first workshop centered around research that focuses on corpora creation, cleansing, and augmentation techniques specifically for machine translation. We accept work that covers any spoken language (including high-resource languages) but we are specifically interested in those submissions that are on languages with limited existing resources (low-resource languages) where resources are not highly available. \r The goal of this workshop is to begin to close the gap between corpora available for low-resource translation systems and promote high-quality data for online systems that can be used by native speakers of low-resource languages is of particular interest. Therefore, It will be beneficial if the techniques presented in research papers include their impact on the quality of MT output and how they can be used in the real world.\r CoCo4MT aims to encourage research on new and undiscovered techniques. We hope that submissions will provide high-quality corpora that is available publicly for download and can be used to increase machine translation performance thus encouraging new dataset creation for multiple languages that will, in turn, provide a general workshop to consult for corpora needs in the future. The workshop\xe2\x80\x99s success will be measured by the following key performance indicators:\r - Promotes the ongoing increase in quality of machine translation systems when measured by standard measurements,\r- Provides a meeting place for collaboration from several research areas to increase the availability of commonly used corpora and new corpora,\r- Drives innovation to address the need for higher quality and abundance of low-resource language data.\r TOPICS\r We are highly interested in original research papers  on the topics below; however, we welcome all novel ideas that cover research on corpora techniques.\r - Difficulties with using existing corpora (e.g., political considerations or domain limitations) and their effects on final MT systems,\r- Strategies for collecting new MT datasets (e.g., via crowdsourcing),\r- Data augmentation techniques,\r- Data cleansing and denoising techniques, \r- Quality control strategies for MT data,\r- Exploration of datasets for pretraining or auxiliary tasks for training MT systems.\r SUBMISSION INFORMATION\r There is one type of submission in the workshop:  Research, review and position paper. The length of each paper should be at least four (4) and not exceed ten (10) pages, plus unlimited pages for references. Submissions should be formatted according to the official AMTA 2022 style templates (PDF, LaTeX, Word). Accepted papers will be published on-line in the AMTA 2022 proceedings which includes the ACL Anthology and will be presented at the conference either orally or as a poster. \r Submissions must be anonymized and should be done using the official conference management system (https://cmt3.research.microsoft.com/AMTA2022). Scientific papers that have been or will be submitted to other venues must be declared as such, and must be withdrawn from the other venues if accepted and published at CoCo4MT. The review will be double-blind. \r We would like to encourage authors to cite papers written in ANY language that are related to the topics, as long as both original bibliographic items and their corresponding English translations are provided.\r Registration will be handled by the main conference. (To be announced)\r IMPORTANT DATES\r June 1, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Call for papers released\rJune 15, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Second call for papers\rJune 29, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Third and final call for papers\rJuly 13, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Paper submissions due\rJuly 27, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93 Notification of acceptance\rAugust 7, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93  Camera-ready due\rAugust 31, 2022 \xe2\x80\x93  Video recordings due\rSeptember 16, 2022 - CoCo4MT workshop\r CONTACT\r CoCo4MT Workshop Organizers\rcoco4mt2022@googlegroups.com\r ORGANIZING COMMITTEE (listed alphabetically)\r Constantine Lignos     Brandeis University\rJohn E. Ortega     New York University and University of Santiago de Compostela (CITIUS)\rKatharina Kann     University of Colorado Boulder\rMaja Popopvi\xc4\x87     ADAPT Centre at Dublin City University\rMarine Carpuat     University of Maryland\rShabnam Tafreshi     University of Maryland\rWilliam Chen     Carnegie Mellon University\r PROGRAM COMMITTEE (listed alphabetically tentative)\r Abteen   Ebrahimi     University of Colorado Boulder\rAdelani  David     Saarland University\rAnanya  Ganesh     University of Colorado Boulder\rAlberto Poncelas     ADAPT Centre at Dublin City University\rAmirhossein Tebbifakhr     University of Trento\t\rAnna Currey     Amazon\rArturo Oncevay     University of Edinburgh\rAtul Kr. Ojha     National University of Ireland Galway\rBharathi Raja Chakravarthi     National University of Ireland Galway\t\rBeatrice Savoldi     University of Trento\rBogdan Babych     Heidelberg University \rBriakou  Eleftheria     University of Maryland\rDossou  Bonaventure     Mila Quebec AI Institute\rDuygu Ataman     New York University\rEleni Metheniti     Universit\xc3\xa9 Toulosse - Paul Sabatier\rFrancis Tyers     Indiana University\rJasper Kyle Catapang     University of Birmingham\rJohn E. Call For Papers: b"\n======================\rPDAA'22: http://is-candar.org/pdaa22/\r The 14th International Workshop on Parallel and Distributed Algorithms and Applications (PDAA'22)\rhttp://is-candar.org/pdaa22/\r To be held in conjunction with CANDAR'22,Himeji, Japan, November 21-24, 2022\rhttp://is-candar.org/\r====================================================\r  [Bridging Theory and Practice in Parallel and Distributed Computing]\r The main goal of this workshop is to provide a timely forum for the exchange and dissemination of new ideas, techniques and research in the field of parallel and distributed algorithms and applications. The workshop is meant to bridge research of theory and practice in all aspects of parallel and distributed computing. We are convinced that the workshop atmosphere will be conducive to open and mutually beneficial exchanges of ideas between the participants of these areas.\r [Topics of interest include, but are not limited to]\r * Theory and Algorithms\rParallel and distributed algorithms, Hardware algorithms,\rGraph-theoretic concepts in parallel and distributed computing,\rGeometric and graph algorithms, Complexity theory in parallel and\rdistributed computing, Parallel and distributed computing models,\rNetwork routing and communication algorithms, Combinatorial\ralgorithms, Randomized and approximation techniques, Cellular Automata\r * Parallel and Distributed Computing\rDNA Computing, Membrane Computing, Quantum Computing, Internet\rComputing, Wireless networks and mobile computing, Internet computing,\rReconfigurable Computing, Internet Computing, Optical Computing\r * Practical Aspects and Applications\rParallel computing systems, Supercomputing, Cluster computing, Grid Computing, Parallel/distributed architectures, P-to-P networks, Performance analysis and simulation, PVM/MPI, CUDA/GPGPU, Multi-core processors, Programmable logic arrays, Reconfigurable Architectures, Image Processing, Security Issues\r [Paper format]\r - Regular paper: 5-7 pages\r- Poster paper: 3-4 pages\r [Submission Instruction]\r Please see Workshop Paper Submission Instruction.\rhttp://is-candar.org/workshop_submission\r [Publication]\r The conference and workshop proceedings will be published by\rConference Publishing Service and submitted to IEEE Xplore and CSDL\rdigital libraries. Also they are submitted for indexing through\rINSPEC, EI (Compendex), Thomson ISI, and other indexing services.\rThey are published in two separated volumes: CANDAR main symposium (CANDAR) \rand CANDAR Workshops (CANDARW).\r [Important dates]\r Workshop abstract submission due: September 5, 2022 (extended, firm)\rWorkshop paper submission due: September 10, 2022 (extended, firm)\rWorkshop paper notification: October 1, 2022\rFinal camera-ready paper submission due: October 21, 2022\rSymposium: November 21-24, 2022.\r [Organizers]\r * Workshop co-chairs\r Sayaka Kamei, Hiroshima University\rFukuhito Ooshita, Fukui University of Technology\r * Program Committee\r St\xc3\xa9phane Devismes, MIS Lab, UR 4290\rRyota Eguchi, Nara Institute of Science and Technology\rAkihiro Fujiwara, Kyushu Institute of Technology\rMasaru Fukushi, Yamaguchi University\rTeijiro Isokawa, University of Hyogo\rYasuaki Ito, Hiroshima University\rChuzo Iwamoto, Hiroshima University\rHirotsugu Kakugawa, Ryukoku University\rRyota Kawashima, Nagoya Institute of Technology\rYonghwan Kim, Nagoya Institute of Technology\rNaoki Kitamura, Osaka University\rTeruaki Kitasuka, Hiroshima University\rAnissa Lamani, Universit\xc3\xa9 de Strasbourg\rLuca Manzoni, University of Trieste\rBruno Martin, Univ. title: b'QCHC-2022 2022'
description: b'Quantum Computing and Health Care'
Call For Papers: b'\nQuantum Computing and Health Care\r NOVA Science Publishers (SCOPUS INDEXED)\rIntroduction\rQuantum technology is approaching the mainstream and gaining more importance in the recent years. It is the mixture of computer science, Quantum physics and also information theory. These technologies play a vital role in various day-to-day applications. This book tries to project the application of quantum computing based concepts in the various emerging technologies which helps in providing solutions for vital applications. \rThe book will also be discussing how to improve healthcare data, such as information from clinical trials, disease registries, electronic health records (EHRs), and medical devices. The data will address various challenges associated with the \xe2\x80\x9cquadruple aim\xe2\x80\x9d of healthcare for the better and lower cost healthcare applications. This will also help in enhancing the patient experiences, and improved healthcare practitioner work lives.\r This book is for describing the following \r1.\tQuantum computing and its application in healthcare sector\r2.\tQuantum computers for EHR\r3.\tDrug design and development\r4.\tPrediction of disease by early diagnosis\r5.\t Quantum Algorithms \r Recommended Topics:\r1.\tDemystifying Quantum Computing\r2.\tQuantum Computers And Substantial Advantages\r3.\tThe Challenges and Concerns of Quantum Computing\r4.\tFuture Health Care With QC\r5.\tQuantum Computer and HER\r6.\tDiagnostic Assistance\r7.\tImprove the analysis of medical images\r8.\tAI/ML Potential To Be Enhancement By By Quantum Computing \r9.\tDrug Design and Development\r10.\tQuantum Computing: A Disruptive Technology \r11.\tApplications in Healthcare\r12.\tAccelerating Diagnoses \r13.\tHealthcare Data and Medical Devices\r14.\tQuantum Enhanced Machine Learning Algorithms\r15.\tPersonalizing Medicine\r16.\tIndustry Oriented Quantum Computing Use Cases.\r17.\tDisease Predictions Using EHR\t \t \r Submission Procedure\r Please Submission chapter Abstract through easychair Link:\r  Important Dates:\r Abstract Submission: July 15, 2022\rFull Chapters Due: Sept. 30, 2022 \r Editors:\r Kavita Saini, Galgotias University, India, kavitasaini_2000@yahoo.com\rPethuru Raj, PhD, Vice President, Reliance Jio Platforms Ltd., Bangalore, India\r\n'

title: b'CPES_2022 2022'
description: b'Cyber Physical Energy Systems: Challenges and Applications'
Categories: b'smart energy management' b'power system resource manageme' b'blockchain for energy sector' b'energy transactions'
Call For Papers: b"\nCall for Book Chapters - Wiley - Scrivener Publishing\r BOOK TITLE: Cyber Physical Energy Systems: Challenges and Applications\r The scope of the book is to endow with an opening for researchers, industrial professionals, scientists, academicians, and practitioners to share their innovative thoughts in the digital transformation of smart grid system and energy system by using Cyber Physical System. A Cyber Physical System (CPS) is an integrated component of physical microgrids that combines computer, wireless connection, and control to create a holistic solution. As a result of the CPS's efforts, a new generation of engineering systems incorporating wireless communication has begun to emerge in recent years. \r Topics of interest (not limited to): \r Chapter 1: Cyber Physical Systems: a control and energy approach\rChapter 2: Optimization techniques for energy management in microgrid\rChapter 3: Cyber Physical Energy Systems for Smart Grid: Reliable Distribution Chapter 4: Analysis of Energy Consumption in cyber-physical systems based power systems\rChapter 5: Cyber Physical Energy Systems in Industrial IoT for energy management\rChapter 6: IoT-based advanced energy management in Smart Factory\rChapter 7: Federated learning based Intelligent Algorithms to control the power losses in power distribution\rChapter 8: Security challenges in CPS based Smart Energy management\rChapter 9: Blockchain based Energy transmission system: Design, Optimization, and data-driven modelling\rChapter 10: Data analytics tools and technologies for energy audit in Cyber Physical Energy Systems\rChapter 11: Infrastructural data visualisation and improved user interfaces of energy consumption in smart cities\rChapter 12: Cyber-physical energy systems for Smart buildings\rChapter 13: Schemes and Security Attacks on the integrity of cyber-physical systems in energy systems\rChapter 14: Adaptive power system resource management in Cyber-physical energy systems. \rChapter 15: Cyber-physical energy systems for Electric Vehicles\rChapter 16: Explainable AI technology in e-CPS: policy design, economic research, and case studies\r   Submission Link:\rhttps://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=cpes-2022 \r  Authors are invited to submit chapter proposals (around 200-250 words) stating the objective and structure of the unpublished research work using the above easychair link. Further instructions for the submission guidelines will be communicated once the proposal is accepted. The final accepted chapters will be indexed in Scopus and Google Scholar.\r  Editors\r             Dr. Shrddha Sagar\rProfessor\r            School of Computing Science and Engineering\r            Galgotias University, Delhi-NCR, India\r Dr. T. Poongodi\r            Professor\r            School of Computing Science and Engineering\r            Galgotias University, Delhi-NCR, India\r Dr. D. Rajesh Kumar, \rProfessor\r            School of Computing Science and Engineering\r            Galgotias University, Delhi-NCR, India\r Dr. Sanjeevikumar Padmanaban\rDepartment of Electrical and Electronics Engineering,\rKPR Institute of Engineering and Technology, India,\rDepartment of Business Development and Technology,\rAarhus University, Denmark.\r\n"

title: b'ICASSP 2023'
description: b'2023 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing'
Categories: b'acoustics' b'speech' b'signal processing'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe 48th IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, & Signal Processing (ICASSP) will be held in Rhodes Island, Greece, from June 4 to June 9, 2023, at the Rodos Palace Luxury Convention Center. The \xef\xac\x82agship conference of the IEEE Signal Processing Society will o\xef\xac\x80er a comprehensive technical program presenting all the latest developments in research and technology for signal processing and its applications. Featuring world-class oral and poster sessions, keynotes, plenaries and perspective talks, exhibitions, demonstrations, tutorials, short courses and satellite workshops, it is expected to attract leading researchers and global industry \xef\xac\x81gures, providing a great networking opportunity.\r Technical Scope: We invite submissions of original unpublished technical papers on topics including but not limited to:\rApplied Signal Processing Systems\rAudio & Acoustic Signal Processing\rBiomedical Imaging & Signal Processing\rCompressive Sensing, Sparse Modeling\rComputational Imaging\rComputer Vision\rDeep Learning/Machine Learning for Signal Processing\rImage, Video & Multidimensional Signal Processing\rIndustrial Signal Processing\rInformation Forensics & Security\rInternet of Things\rMultimedia Signal Processing\rQuantum Signal Processing\rRemote Sensing & Signal Processing\rSensor Array & Multichannel SP\rSignal Processing for Big Data\rSignal Processing for Communication\rSignal Processing for Cyber Security\rSignal Processing for Education\rSignal Processing for Robotics\rSignal Processing Over Graphs\rSignal Processing Theory & Methods\rSpeech and Language Processing\rLocation: Rhodes is the capital of the Dodecanese group of islands in the southeast Aegean archipelagos, where east meets west. Rich in historic heritage, it has been a crossroad of many civilizations and features a UNESCO-heritage medieval old town. It o\xef\xac\x80ers a cosmopolitan mix of a vibrant city lifestyle, idyllic beaches, historic tours, easy access to other Greek islands and many other Mediterranean attractions. Rhodes airport has direct air connections to many European cities.\r Call for Tutorials and Special Sessions: Tutorials are an important component of ICASSP\xe2\x80\x99s program, providing the opportunity to learn about current research areas of growing interest to the community. The program will also include Special Sessions complementing the main program, in line with the technical scope of the conference.\r Call for Workshops, Seasonal Schools, Short Courses: We are proud to present satellite events that enrich the program, attract wide audience and provide inclusivity for students and young professionals.\r Call for Exhibitors and Sponsors: To showcase their products and innovative solutions, as well as recruitment and networking opportunities. Please check the conference webpage for information about signing up to become an exhibitor or sponsor at ICASSP 2023.\r SP Society Journal Paper Presentations: Authors of papers published or accepted in IEEE SPS journals may present their work at ICASSP 2023 at appropriate tracks. These papers will neither be reviewed nor included in the proceedings. In addition, the IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing (OJSP) will provide a special track for longer submissions with the same processing timeline as ICASSP. Accepted papers will be published in OJSP and presented in the conference but will not be included in the conference proceedings.\r Open Preview: Conference proceedings will be available in IEEE Xplore, free of charge, to all customers, 30 days prior to the conference start date, through the conference end date.\r Important Dates:\rSpecial Session Proposals  18 August 2022\rPaper Submissions  19 October 2022\rTutorial Proposals  02 November 2022\rGrand Challenge Proposals  09 November 2022\rWorkshop, Seasonal School, Short Course Proposals  09 November 2022\rAuthor Response Period  06-17 January 2023\rPaper Acceptance  08 February 2023\rSPS Journal Papers/Letters Deadline  08 February 2023\rCamera Ready Paper Deadline  06 March 2023\rShow and Tell Proposals  07 March 2023\rAuthor Registration  20 March 2023\rOpen Preview Starts  05 May 2023\n\t'

title: b'ISTC 2023'
description: b'International Symposium on Topics in Coding'
Categories: b'coding theory' b'forward error correction' b'coded modulation'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe 12th International Symposium on Topics in Coding* will be held from Monday September 4th to Friday September 8th, 2023, in Brest, France. The symposium will be an opportunity to acquire a broad overview of the current status of advanced research in all areas of coding theory and its applications. All original contributions will be considered, in both theoretical and applied fields. Topics for submission include, but are not limited to, the following:\r Error-control coding\rTurbo, LDPC, polar, and product-like codes\rCoded modulation\rCode design for short-packet communications\rHigh-throughput decoding\rHardware and software implementations\rPerformance bounds\rIterative equalization and detection\rMessage-passing algorithms\rJoint source-channel coding\rCoding for optical communications\rCoding for wireless communications\rCoding for storage and computation\rQuantum error correction\rMulti-user coding techniques\rMachine learning applied to codes and decoders design\r In addition, papers that broaden the reach of coding, including emerging fields and novel applications of coding, are encouraged. The symposium will include regular papers for oral and poster sessions as well as invited papers.\n\t'

title: b'ReWoRDS 2022'
description: b'2nd Workshop on Reproducible Workflows, Data Management, and Security'
Categories: b'reproducibility' b'workflows' b'data management' b'security'
Call For Papers: b"\nConference website\thttps://sites.google.com/view/rewords22/home\rSubmission link\thttps://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=rewords22\r Submission deadline\tJuly 8, 2022\r Topics: reproducibility for big data/ai workflows data management tools and techniques provenance management techniques and tools reproducibility efforts and techniques\r This workshop explores innovations and experiences around developing portable, general, reproducible workflows while paying attention to providing open data with verifiable authenticity while protecting privacy, where needed. We are looking for community discussion and participation on the above topics plus the following. First, component packaging via containers and virtual machines, automation scripting, deployment, portability builds, and system support for these and other relevant activities. Second, provenance collection, exploration, and tracking are key for a well-documented scientific output. Third, issues with managing large data sets and workflow intermediate data, particularly those intended to manage publicly accessed data for use and reuse are encouraged. Finally, new techniques and technologies that address portability and reproducibility requirements, such as those required for peer reviewed publication, are also requested.\r Submission Guidelines\rAll papers must be original and not simultaneously submitted to another journal or conference. The following paper categories are welcome:\r Full papers describing emerging and future computational workloads are combining traditional HPC applications with tools and techniques from the scale out data analytics and machine learning community. Getting these technologies to co-exist and interoperate to advance scientific discovery is a daunting task with few known good solutions. In general, constructing these workflows has the potential to create pitfalls and incompatibilities that limit adoption.\r Formalizing the steps necessary for an application or data processing pipeline is increasingly popular and necessary. Requirements for reproducibility artifacts for publishing venues are also driving this formalization. The processes and infrastructure to accomplish these requirements are frequently bespoke or custom for a particular research area. All of these formalization activities can be described as workflow systems. Existing off-the-shelf tools address a distributed environment fairly well, but are not complete solutions and do not address the scale up community much, if at all.\r Complicating managing workflows are the tasks of managing data both during workflow execution and then afterwards as well as offering authentication and data security for shared data sets. With some data, such as climate simulation output, being subject to intense scrutiny, it becomes crucial to offer open data that can be verified as authentic by means of encrypted creator identities, and accessible only to people with a need to know. Sharing and analyzing the data knowing it is authentic while protecting the privacy of the creators is essential for reliable open science, while protecting the identity of the scientists performing the work.\r This workshop seeks to explore ideas and experiences on what kinds of infrastructure developments can improve upon the state of the art. Explorations of component packaging via containers and virtual machines, automation scripting, deployment, portability builds, and system support for these and other relevant activities are key infrastructure. Provenance collection, exploration, and tracking are key for a well documented scientific output. Using existing systems to achieve these goals via experiences are important for developing best practices that span application domains. Data privacy techniques such as multi-party encryption and differential privacy are important as well. Issues with managing large data sets and workflow intermediate data, particularly those intended to manage publicly accessed data for use and reuse are encouraged. New techniques and technologies that address reproducibility requirements are also requested. We seek work on all of these, and related, topics as well as position and experience papers looking to drive conversation for practitioners and researchers in these spaces.\r This workshop contributes by sharing experiences and exploring the various technological infrastructure needs to support effective, convenient workflow systems and application composition structures and approaches across a broad spectrum of HPC environments from clusters to supercomputers to cloud systems.\r Paper submission guidelines: \r Papers should be formatted in IEEE format following eScience formatting rules and can be 5 pages not including references. The format of the paper should be of double column text using single spaced 10 point size on 8.5 x 11 inch pages, as per IEEE 8.5 x 11 manuscript guidelines. Templates are available from this link.\r List of Topics\rPosition and Experience papers related to scientific applications and platforms on related topics (particularly the topics listed below)\rBig Data or AI workflow systems like Spark, Hadoop, and Tensorflow in conjunction with data management and reproducibility efforts and techniques\rFront end systems for configuring or controlling workflows\rData management tools and techniques\rPrivacy preserving methods to enable data sharing\rWorkflow engines designed to simplify workflow construction for end users\rProvenance management and collection techniques and tools\rApplication-specific workflow implementations\rMechanisms to support combining multiple application components into a composite application or workflow\rSoftware engineering tools and techniques to support workflow creation, execution, and use\rReproducibility supporting infrastructure\rIn situ analytics or visualization support for workflows\rSystem software/OS features to enable workflow tools and application composition\rProgramming support for assembling workflows or connecting application components\rReusable components intended as either ''glue'' between workflow components or for analysis or other processing\rStorage (both disk and in compute area) support for buffering between components\rProgramming support for addressing data format/contents mismatch\rProgramming support for resource management\r Program Committee\rClaire Bowen (Urban Institute)\rJuliana Freire (Reprozip)\rLo\xc3\xafc Pottier: (ISI)\rRafael Ferreira Da Silva (ISI)\rJakob L\xc3\xbcttgau: (UTK)\rTom Peterka (ANL)\rJay Jay Billings (Amazon)\rMargo Seltzer (Harvard)\rHariharan Devarajan (LLNL)\rDmitry Duplyakin (NREL)\rOrganizing committee\rJay Lofstead (Sandia)\rJai Dayal (Intel)\rAnthony Kougkas (IIT)\rPaula Olaya (UTK)\r Contact\rAll questions about submissions should be emailed to gflofst@sandia.gov\r\n"

title: b'MLBEM 2022'
description: b'2nd Workshop on Machine Learning for Buildings Energy Management'
Categories: b'machine learning' b'smart buildings' b'building energy management'
Call For Papers: b"\n2nd Workshop on Machine Learning for Buildings Energy Management (MLBEM 2022)\r Co-located with ECMLPKDD 2022, the European Conference on Machine Learning and Principles and Practice of Knowledge Discovery in Databases, which will be held on September 19-23 2022 in Grenoble.\r The MLBEM workshop will be fully organized *online*.\r -----------------------------------------------------------------------\r*** OVERVIEW ***\r-----------------------------------------------------------------------\rIncreased energy efficiency and decarbonization of the energy system are two primary objectives of the European Energy Union.\rEuropean buildings remain predominantly inefficient, accounting for 40% of final energy consumption and 36% of the total EU CO2 emissions.\rMachine learning is a key enabler of scalable and efficient tools for building energy assessment and for the development of services capable of dealing with the increased complexity of energy management in buildings generated by the electrification of the energy system.\rThe aim of this workshop is to provide energy and machine learning researchers with a forum to exchange and discuss scientific contributions, open challenges, and recent achievements in machine learning and their role in the development of efficient and scalable building energy management systems.\r The workshop aims at filling a gap in the EU workshop panorama, providing researchers with a forum to exchange and discuss scientific contributions and open challenges, both theoretical and practical, related to the use of machine-learning approaches in building energy management.\rWe want to foster joint work and knowledge exchange between the building's energy community, researchers, and practitioners from the machine learning area, and its crossing with big data, data science, and visualization.\rThe workshop shall provide a forum for discussing novel trends and achievements in machine learning and their role in developing scalable BEMs. It aims to highlight the latest research trends in machine learning, privacy of data, big data, deep learning, incremental and stream learning, and adversarial learning.\rIn particular, it aims to promote the application of these emerging ML techniques to buildings energy management.\r The workshop shall contribute to identifying new application areas as well as open and future research problems related to the application of machine-learning in the building's energy field.\r Website: http://mlbem.lasige.di.fc.ul.pt/\r -----------------------------------------------------------------------\r*** IMPORTANT DATES ***\r-----------------------------------------------------------------------\r Paper submission deadline: June 27, 2022\rAcceptance notification: July 18, 2022\rCamera ready submission: July 29, 2022\r -----------------------------------------------------------------------\r*** SUBMISSION GUIDELINES ***\r-----------------------------------------------------------------------\rSubmissions are accepted in two formats:\r 1) Regular research papers with 12 to 16 pages including references.\rTo be published in the proceedings, research papers must be original, not published previously, and not submitted concurrently elsewhere.\r 2) Short research statements of at most 6 pages. Research statements aim at fostering discussion and collaboration.\rThey may review research published previously or outline new emerging ideas.\r Submission website: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=mlbem2022\r -----------------------------------------------------------------------\r*** TOPICS ***\r-----------------------------------------------------------------------\rMachine Learning for:\r    - buildings energy performance assessment\r    - appliance and building technical equipment energy assessment\r    - buildings occupancy assessment\r    - energy flexibility management\r    - buildings energy efficiency\r    - building-as-a-battery\r    - thermal comfort estimation and control\r    - buildings lighting control\r    - buildings' air quality control\r    - holistic control of buildings systems and energy resources\r    - distributed energy resources management\rAdversarial machine learning and the robustness of AI in BEM\rInterpretability and explainability of machine learning models in BEM\rPrivacy preserving machine learning in BEM\rTrusted machine learning\rScalable/big data approaches for BEM\rContinuous and one-shot learning\rInformed machine learning\rUser and entity behavior modeling and analysis\r -----------------------------------------------------------------------\r*** ORGANIZERS ***\r-----------------------------------------------------------------------\rPedro Ferreira, University of Lisbon\rGuilherme Gra\xc3\xa7a, University of Lisbon\r Website: http://mlbem.lasige.di.fc.ul.pt/\rSubmission website: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=mlbem2022\n\t"
