Call For Papers: b'\n[Apologies for cross posting]\r Call for Papers\r12th International Global Wordnet Conference\rDonostia / San Sebastian, Basque Country\rJanuary 23-27, 2023\r Global Wordnet Association: www.globalwordnet.org\r Conference website: https://hitz.eus/gwc2023\r The Global Wordnet Association is pleased to announce the 12th International Global Wordnet Conference (GWC2023) in Donostia / San Sebastian (Spain) hosted by HiTZ, Basque Center for Language Technology at the University of the Basque Country.\r NOTE: COVID-19 allowing, the conference will be in person only.\rOrganisers: Bego\xc3\xb1a Altuna, Itziar Aldabe, Xabier Arregi, Itziar Gonzalez-Dios, Aritz Farwell and  Esther Miranda.\r Details about the Association and the full announcement for the conference can be found on the conference website: https://hitz.eus/gwc2023\r We invite submissions with original contributions addressing, but not limited to, the topics listed below. Proposals for tutorials are welcome as well.\r Conference Topics\r Lexical semantics and meaning representation\r* Critical analysis and applications of lexical and semantic relations\r* Proposed new relations\r* Definitions, semantic components, co-occurrence and frequency statistics\r* Word, Sense and Context Embeddings\r* Necessity and completeness issues\r* Ontology and wordnet\r* Other lexicographical and lexicological questions pertaining to wordnet-style meaning representation\r* Wordnets and other modalities\r Architecture of lexical databases\r* Language independent and language dependent components\r* Integration of multi-wordnets in research infrastructures (like CLARIN, ELG, etc.) \r* Wordnets and Linked Open Data (LOD)\rTools and methods for wordnet development\r* User and Data entry interfaces\r* Methods for constructing, extending and enriching wordnets\r* Methods for linking wordnets to other lexical and semantic resources\r* Methods for leveraging existing wordnets and semantic networks with large language models\r Applications of wordnet\r* Word sense disambiguation\r* Text generation\r* Commonsense reasoning\r* Machine translation\r* Information extraction and retrieval\r* Document structuring and categorisation\r* Automatic hyperlinking\r* Language pedagogy\r* Psycholinguistic applications\r* Embeddings and pretrained language models\r* Probing large neural language models\r Standardization, distribution and availability of wordnets and wordnet tools.\r Submissions will fall into one of the following categories (page limits exclude references):\r* long papers: 8 pages max, 30 minutes presentation\r* short papers: 5 pages max; 15 minutes presentation\r* project reports: 5 pages max., 10 minutes presentation\r* demonstrations : 5 pages max, with an additional 3 pages screen dumps or images; 20 minutes presentation\r Submissions should be anonymous and any identifying information must be removed. Authors must state the preferred category, though acceptance may be subject to change in the category of the presentation, e.g. a long paper submission may be accepted as a short paper.\rFinal papers should be submitted in electronic form (PDF only).\rPaper submission site will be online soon.\rPaper submissions must use the official ACL style templates, which are available from here (Latex and Word). Please follow the paper formatting guidelines general to \xe2\x80\x9c*ACL\xe2\x80\x9d conferences available here. Authors may not modify these style files or use templates designed for other conferences.\r Important Dates\rSeptember 30, 2022 Deadline for paper submission\rNovember 18, 2022 Notification of acceptance\rDecember 1, 2022 Registration opens\rDecember 23, 2022 Deadline author registration, final version paper\rJanuary 23-27, 2023 Conference\r Proceedings\rConference proceedings will be open access and downloadable from the GWA website. The proceedings will have an ISBN and be published in the ACL anthology.\rPapers are only included in the proceedings if at least one author has registered.\rInclusion of accepted submissions into the final program and the proceedings is contingent upon at least one author\xe2\x80\x99s registration. Late registration and on-site registration for participants is possible without inclusion of the paper and without presentation.\r Conference Chairs\rGerman Rigau - german.rigau@ehu.eus\rFrancis Bond - title: b'UCC 2022'
description: b'15th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing'
Call For Papers: b'\nThe digital transformation of all areas of life is accelerated in this decade by novel cloud services, e-infrastructures, data platforms and cyber-physical system integration. This broader scope of cloud computing calls for technically sound contributions that combine scale with convenience and reliability. Society and economy depend on cloud applications delivering compute power on demand in every location along data paths as a general service to the public, in analogy to conventional utilities. The engineering of such systems and applications calls for scientifically proven approaches, methods, tools and technologies.\r Providing a forum to review and discuss possible solutions, UCC is the premier IEEE/ACM conference for areas related to Cloud Computing as a Utility where leading researchers and practitioners in this important and growing field gather on an annual basis.\r This will be the 15th UCC in a successful conference series of community-driven events. Previous events were held in Shanghai, China (Cloud 2009), Melbourne, Australia (Cloud 2010 & UCC 2011), Chennai, India (UCC 2010), Chicago, USA (UCC 2012), Dresden, Germany (UCC 2013), London, UK (UCC 2014), Limassol, Cyprus (UCC 2015), Shanghai, China (UCC 2016), Austin, Texas, USA (UCC 2017), Zurich, Switzerland (UCC 2018), Auckland, New Zealand (UCC 2019), online during the pandemic (UCC 2020), and Leicester, UK (UCC 2021).\r UCC 2022 will be hosted at Washington State University. Portland, Oregon\xe2\x80\x99s largest city, sits on the Columbia and Willamette rivers, in the shadow of snow-capped Mount Hood.\r UCC 2022 offers a technical programme, workshops, tutorials, and a doctoral symposium. The event will have a co-located 9th International Conference on Big Data Computing Applications and Technologies (BDCAT 2022).\r Authors are invited to submit original, unpublished research manuscripts in all areas of Cloud and Utility Computing and related computing paradigms such as Fog/Edge, Serverless and Distributed Computing.\r Authors of accepted papers can opt into reproducible research decoration to publish according to open science conventions; the details are described below.\rTopics of interest include (but not limited to)\r     Formal and qualitative aspects of Cloud technology\r    Security, trust, privacy and policies in Clouds, and Cloud-hosted Blockchains\r    Artificial intelligence in Clouds, and Cloud applications\r    Architectural models and patterns to achieve Utility in Clouds\r    Cloud business and legal implications beyond technology\r    Cloud Computing middleware, stacks, tools, delivery networks and services at all layers (XaaS)\r    Cloud large-scale foundations for Big Data, IoT, and real-time analytics\r    Cloud management: autonomic, adaptive, self-*, SLAs, and monitoring\r    Cloud-native application design, programming models, engineering and serverless/microservice implementation\r    Cloud, Micro data centers, Fog and edge/mobile devices management, hierarchy models, and business models\r    Designs and deployment models for Clouds: private, public, hybrid, federated, aggregated, intercloud\r    Economic and business models of Clouds and services\r    High Performance Computing and the Cloud\r    Innovative cloud applications and experiences, including quantum clouds and IoT-fog/edge-cloud continuums\r    Mobile and energy-efficient use of Clouds\r    Networking for clouds and data centers\r    Performance analysis and modelling of cloud systems and applications\r    Principles and theoretical foundations of Utility Computing\r    Resource management and scalability: brokering, scheduling, capacity planning, and elasticity\r    Utility-driven platforms for Clouds\r    Utility-driven models and mechanisms for cloud applications in all domains (smart cities, mobility, e-health, industry etc.)\r    Virtualization, containerization, composition, orchestration and other enablers\r Paper Submission\r Submitted manuscripts must represent original unpublished research that is not currently under review for any other conference or journal. Manuscripts are submitted in PDF format and may not exceed ten (10) single-spaced double-column pages using 10-point size font on 8.5x11 inch pages (IEEE conference style), including figures, tables, and references. The limit is six (6) pages for workshop papers.\r All manuscripts will be reviewed and judged on correctness, originality, technical strength, rigor in analysis, quality of results, quality of presentation, and interest and relevance to the conference attendees.\r Accepted papers will be invited to undergo an artefact evaluation process that will determine availability of code/data or even reproducibility. An independent committee will handle this process and send the invite along with instructions after the acceptance notification.\r At least one author of each paper must be registered for the conference in order for the paper to be published in the proceedings. The proceedings will be published by the IEEE Computer Society and will be made available online through the IEEE Digital Library, as well as through the ACM Digital Library.\r Formatting: https://www.ieee.org/conferences/publishing/templates.html\r Main track submissions: https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ucc2022\r Workshop submissions: see respective workshop information\n\t'

title: b'AI-DH 2022'
description: b'MDPI Big Data and Cognitive Computing - Special Issue on Artificial Intelligence in Digital Humanities'
Call For Papers: b'\nDear Colleagues,\r It is our pleasure to announce a new Special Issue \xe2\x80\x9cArtificial Intelligence in Digital Humanities\xe2\x80\x9d of the journal Big Data and Cognitive Computing.\r Recent advances in specialized equipment and computational methods have had a significant impact on the digital humanities and, particularly, cultural heritage and archaeology research. Nowadays, digital technology applications contribute on a daily basis to recording, preservation, research and dissemination in the digital humanities. Digitization is the defining practice that bridges science and technology with the humanities, either in tangible or in the intangible forms. The digital replicas enable a wide range of studies, opening new horizons in humanities research. Advances in artificial intelligence and its successful application in core technical domains brings new possibilities to support humanities research in particularly demanding and challenging tasks.\r AI applications in humanities research have a significant impact on multi-model and multi-dimensional information sharing and the representation of knowledge, enabling a reflection on historical trends, culture and identity. AI has already been used in a diverse set of applications, ranging from effective asset organization and knowledge representation to virtual and cyber archaeology, advanced and extended visualization, asset and context interpretation, intelligent tools, personalized access, and to gamification and public dissemination.\r This Special Issue focuses on the forthcoming future of artificial intelligence applications in digital humanities, including recent developments ranging from deep and reinforcement learning approaches to recommendation technologies in the extended reality domain.\r AI is currently reshaping humanities research, and the following research areas are just broad indicative cases of this evolution: digitization and preventive preservation with AI; interpretation and restoration with AI; predictive modelling with AI; heritage analytics with AI; dissemination with AI; personalization and inclusive design with AI.\r In this Special Issue, original research articles and reviews are welcome. Research areas may include (but are not limited to) the following:\r - Advanced, multi-scale, multi-modal and automated digitization;\r- Big data approaches in digital humanities;\r- From digital to cyber humanities;\r- Preventive preservation;\r- Climate change and heritage protection;\r- Decoding of ancient epigraph marks;\r- Deciphering of ancient languages, texts, epigraphs;\r- Automatic restoration of lost texts and images;\r- Predictive modeling in humanities research;\r- Digital resources with open linked data and semantic web capacity;\r- Advanced analysis and annotation of artifacts;\r- AI approaches in heritage science and physicochemical analysis;\r- Authentication, traceability and prevention of illicit trafficking;\r- Citizen science, and citizen involvement;\r- Extended (virtual, augmented, etc.) reality applications;\r- Advanced personalization and recommender technologies;\r- Inclusive design.\r\n'

title: b'Special Issue 2022'
description: b"'Frontiers in the Sustainability and Resilience Interface at the Urban and Regional Levels: Sciences, Plans, Policies, and Actions for the Next Challenging Decades'"
Categories: b'sustainability' b'resilience' b'urban and regional studies' b'supply chains'
Call For Papers: b'\nDear Colleagues,\r The current and next decades promise to be difficult ones. Long-anticipated resource scarcity, pollution, and global warming are all likely to become increasingly tangible, with the potential to drastically change the world as we know it, including cities and what nourishes them from the outside. Supply shortages, extreme weather, new health emergencies, and geopolitical tensions may depict uncertain scenarios that, however, cannot be left waiting, simply labelled as black swan events. Present evidence and scientific forecasts about climate change and its tipping points have recently led even United Nations Secretary-General Ant\xc3\xb3nio Guterres to make desperate pleas for urgent action, since the very future of humanity is at stake.\r Discourses on sustainability and resilience have multiplied in recent times, yet with frequently different meanings of these concepts and often with local or sectorial applications. We may argue that the present and upcoming challenges demand more: sustainability as the ambitious goal to restore human rhythms able to be also feasible in the future, starting from resource use, waste and pollution production, and induced climate change, without compromising the liveableness of the next (and\xe2\x80\x94alas\xe2\x80\x94also our) generations, and without forgetting the social dimensions, starting from equity; resilience as a no less ambitious effort to reduce the vulnerability of human systems, to overcome and to adapt to shocks and drastic changes, whose causes, partly triggered by past and present mistakes, must also be addressed through sustainability-seeking actions.\r This Special Issue aims at addressing the underexplored sustainability and resilience interface by keeping in mind the deepest meanings of these concepts, as well as the uncertainty and the unpleasant hints about the turbulent era we are approaching. Of course, the past and existing valuable experiences with sustainability and resilience may be addressed and reported too, but their critical assessment and discussion, in light of the above, is strongly encouraged here.\r While well aware of the pressing needs that may affect scientific research and professional practice (including, but not limited to, the dependency upon funding and structural disciplinary boundaries), hard times can be seen as an occasion to move further. Aware, critical, and forward-looking contributions about sciences, plans, policies, and actions to effectively reduce the unsustainability and increase the resilience of human systems in a difficult epoch like this are all welcome, with a preference for urban and regional systems and for their interconnections with the many sectors upon which they depend.\r Dr. Silvio Cristiano\rGuest Editor\n\t'

title: b'MINA 2022'
description: b'Memory and Identity in North Africa'
Categories: b'memory studies' b'social sciences' b'humanities' b'history and identity'
Call For Papers: b'\nBackground\rMemory Studies is a multifaceted academic discipline that is situated at the juncture of history, social sciences and culture. From its humble beginnings as a mnemo-technic to its complicated uses in psychology and psychoanalysis, memory has stirred wide and transformative questions, particularly with its deployment in sociology. Halbwachs\xe2\x80\x99 notion of collective memory (1925) has since been a fixture of what became known as Memory Studies. This movement toward the social has led to the profusion of works around \xe2\x80\x9ccollective memory,\xe2\x80\x9d which Olick and Robbins (1998) claim, became the core of scholarly exploration in early 20th century. Varied disciplines, such as literature, sociology, archive science, and historiography, among others, draw on the epistemological frameworks that developed the fields that engage with remembering. The rise in interest in commemorative practices after WWI and WWII has brought attention to genealogies, biographies, diaries, museums, and monuments, giving more presence to questions of trauma, loss, memory and history. Hence Memory studies have directed attention to the ways in which memory has become a cultural and sociological practice whose roots are entangled in political and identitarian issues and institutions (Assmann 1995; Rothberg 1993).\rMemory has become the glue that cements groups and communities, endowing them with commonalties that allow them to build shared ethos and identities. Ironically, Pierre Nora has written that "we speak so much of memory because there is so little of it left\xe2\x80\x9d (1984) or rather because memories occupy such a pivotal place in shaping national identities that there is not enough of it. Sites of memory, commemorative practices, museums, historiographical projects, autobiographies, rituals, pilgrimages, and annual celebrations of victories are all deeply immersed in memory, which shapes the commemorating societies\xe2\x80\x99 present in light of their past. However, there is a significant difference between memory practices in the Global North and their counterparts in the Global South. The North suffers from a glut of memory whereas the Global South has yet to fully account for seminal historical events that have far-reaching resonances for its nations and societies. While there is a focus on memories of resistance to colonialism, one can easily observe the selective nature of commemorations. Specifically, memory in North Africa, which is a vast region with an incredible cultural diversity, has been mostly driven by statal actors who focus on official aspects of the past. Groups and communities that did not fit the national narratives were simply left out (Boum 2013).\rImazighen, Arabs, sub-Saharans, and Jews are some of the groups that have yet to occupy their rightful place in North African memory. Although these groups are heavily present in the quotidian life of their societies, both physically and symbolically, their inclusion in the commemorative projects will be salutary for the future of these societies. The public sphere has not been amply flexile for the diverse cultural identities of the region, affecting the way renditions of the past are reenacted in the present. Official memories have overshadowed other memories, leading to the appearance of marginal sites of commemoration (El Guabli 2019). The overpowering presence of an official, unifying approach to memory counters the very essential trait of memories as being diverse, in-flux, and malleable.\rThis conference aims to reflect on a rich array of memory-focused topics, including performance rituals, celebrations, festivals, objects, places, literature, artifacts, and specific historical moments using the interdisciplinary methodologies honed in Memory Studies. We seek papers that draw on Memory Studies to reflect on issues related to identity, history, historiography, commemoration, remembrance, and changing conceptions of the self and the collective in North Africa. Thus, we ask how much memory is present in the North African spheres? How have\rmemories of the past in North Africa been promoted and appropriated for the sake of a more flexible public sphere? Who are the memory stakeholders? How do they mobilize memory? What place do minority memories occupy in the grand narratives of different states? Can \xe2\x80\x98subaltern\xe2\x80\x99 memories exist and be performed in public?\rWe invite scholars in all disciplines to submit their proposals. The themes of papers may include, but are not restricted to, the topics of:\r- (Post)Colonial Memories in North Africa\r- Memory dynamics and the Public Sphere in the Maghreb\r- Representations of cultural memory in literature in North Africa\r- Competitive/comparative models of cultural memory in North African states\r- Memories and Trauma transformation\r- Cultural memory in institutional discourse\r- Amazigh memories/identities in North Africa\r- Narratives of Jewish memories/identities in North Africa\r- Migrants\xe2\x80\x99 Memories across borders\r- Cultural memory in Film and Music\r- \xe2\x80\x98Vernacular\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98Subaltern\xe2\x80\x99 Memories\r- Cultural Memory in individual Diaries, Memoirs, and (Auto)biographies\r- Memories and Identities in History Textbooks\r- Museums, Monuments, and Photographs\r- Digital Memories and Modes of Transmission\r- Transitional/Restorative Justice and Memory\rBy hosting an interdisciplinary conference, we hope to cross-fertilize local engagements with memory by a wider engagement with the approaches and methodologies that have been generative in other academic settings and social contexts.\r Confirmed Keynote speakers:\r Dr. Aomar Boum                                Dr. Brahim El Guabli\rUniversity of California Los-Angeles, CA      Williams College, Massachusetts\rPlease submit a 400-word abstract as well as a short bio to the organizing committee (minaconference2022@gmail.com) by July 5, 2022. Abstracts should contextualize the topic and explain the argument in order to allow the organizing committee to put papers in conversation.\n\t'

title: b'GRAPH-QUALITY@ECML-PKDD 2022'
description: b'GRAPH-QUALITY Workshop Co-located with ECML-PKDD'

Call For Papers: b'\nCall For Papers: GRAPH-QUALITY Workshop Co-located with ECML-PKDD, 23 September 2022\r https://graphquality.github.io/\r ******************************************************************************************\r [Please accept our apologies if you receive multiple copies of this Call for Papers (CFP)]\r The GRAPH-QUALITY Workshop at ECML-PKDD 2022 aims to explore the theoretical and practical aspects of quality of data, models and evaluation in the context of graph-based data mining and machine learning. We invite contributions in the area of Data and Model Quality for Mining and Learning with relational data (measures, algorithms, models, tools, evaluations, etc.) to be presented at the GRAPH-QUALITY workshop which is to be held at the European Conference on Machine Learning and Principles and Practices of Knowledge Discovery from Data (ECML-PKDD), in Grenoble, France - 23 September 2022.\r Topics of interests\r     Anomaly detection on graphs\r    Assessment of fairness and bias in the context of graphs, graph models (including representations), and subsequent tasks such as link prediction\r    Explainable graph models and predictions\r    Graph models and representations learning in the context of missing data and noise\r    Privacy preserving data mining and machine learning for relational data\r    Probabilistic methods and uncertainty estimation on networks\r    Algorithms and metrics for quality preservation on relational data\r Submission Information\r All papers will be peer-reviewed single-blind. We welcome many kinds of papers, such as (and not limited to):\r     Novel research papers\r    Work-in-progress papers\r    Vision and position papers\r    Appraisal papers of existing methods and tools (e.g., evaluations, lessons learned)\r Authors should indicate in their abstract the kind of submissions that the paper belongs to, to help reviewers better understand their contributions. Submissions must be in PDF, written in English and formatted according to the single-column CEUR-ART style (downloadable at http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-XXX/CEURART.zip). Novel research papers should be 10 to 16 pages (including references), work-in-progress, vision/position, and appraisal papers should be 6-10 pages (including references). Accepted papers will be presented as a poster in the poster sessions and a few will be selected to also give an oral presentation.\r Authors may opt-in to have their paper possibly published in workshop proceedings at CEUR-WS. All papers will be posted on the workshop website. The proceedings containing the opt-in papers will be submitted for inclusion to CEUR-WS. Assuming a sufficient number of high-quality papers, the proceedings are likely to be accepted, but conforming to CEUR-WS policy it cannot guarantee beforehand that the proceedings will indeed be published. Papers in the CEUR-WS series are published Open Access, without fee, under the CC-BY 4.0 licence (exceptions for Crown or US government employees). You as the author remain to hold the copyright.\r For accepted papers, at least one author must register for the conference and attend the workshop in-person to present the work.\r  Submit via EasyChair: https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=graphquality2022\r Important Dates\r Submission: June 30, 2022\r Notification: July 18, 2022\r Early registration deadline for the conference: July 22, 2022\r Camera-ready: August 12, 2022\r Programme and papers online: Monday 5 Sep 2022\r Workshop date: September 23, 2022\r Futher information and Contact\r Organizers: Nidhi Hegde, Christine Largeron, Jefrey Lijffijt, Osmar R. Za\xc3\xafane\r Website URL: https://graphquality.github.io/\r E-mail: graphquality22@gmail.com \r\n'

title: b'NarSUM 2022'
description: b'The 1st Workshop on User-Centric Narrative Summarization of Long Videos'
Categories: b'video summarization' b'narrative summary of videos' b'video storytelling' b'action & scene graph generatio'
Call For Papers: b'\n===============================================================================\rThe 1st Workshop on User-Centric Narrative Summarization of Long Videos (NarSUM)\r(In conjunction with ACM MM 2022, Oct 10-14, 2022, Lisbon, Portugal)\r===============================================================================\rWorkshop website: https://narsum.cf/\r With video capture devices becoming widely popular, the amount of video data generated per day has seen a rapid increase over the past few years. Browsing through hours of video data to retrieve useful information is a tedious and boring task. Video Summarization technology has played a crucial role in addressing this issue. It is a well-researched topic in the multimedia community. However, the focus so far has been limited to creating summary to videos which are short (only a few minutes).\r This workshop aims to call for researchers on relevant background to focus on novel solutions for user-centric narrative summarization of long videos. Specifically, the goal is to provide the users with meaningful information and insights from long input videos, potentially captured from multiple cameras. Since the generated output of any video summarization task will be finally consumed by humans, it is also important to have an element of storytelling, where the resulting summary is presented in the form of a narrative for humans to understand easily. This workshop will also cover other important aspects of video summarization research like what is "important" in a video, how to evaluate the goodness of a created summary, etc.\r --------------------------------------------------\rTOPICS OF INTEREST (including but not limited to)\r--------------------------------------------------\r* Summarization of single/multiple long videos\r* Action and scene graph generation from videos\r* Narrative summary and video storytelling\r* Datasets for long video summarization\r* Novel evaluation criteria/metrics\r* Novel application of long video summarization\r* Open challenges in video summarization\r* Privacy preserved video summarization\r ------------------------------\rIMPORTANT DATES\r------------------------------\r* Paper submission deadline: July 15, 2022\r* Acceptance notification: July 31, 2022\r* Camera-ready submission: August 7, 2022\r ------------------------------\rPAPER SUBMISSION\r------------------------------\rAll submissions (including Work-In-Progress) must be original works not under review at any other workshop, conference, or journal. Submitted papers may consist of 6 to 8 pages, with up to two additional pages for references. Submitted papers must use the ACM Article Template and conform to the double-blind review policy. For more details, please check the submission guidelines in the workshop homepage.\r ------------------------------\rAWARDS\r------------------------------\rA cash prize of $500 USD will be awarded as the best paper award.\r ------------------------------\rORGANIZING COMMITTEE\r------------------------------\rGeneral chair\r* Mohan. S. Kankanhalli, National University of Singapore\r Program co-chairs\r* Jianquan Liu, NEC Corporation, Japan\r* Yongkang Wong,  National University of Singapore\r Organizing co-chairs\r* Karen Stephen, NEC Corporation, Japan\r* Anusha Bhamidipati, NEC Corporation, Japan\r* Rishabh Sheoran,  National University of Singapore\r Web&SNS chair\r* Takahiro Komamizu, Nagoya University, Japan\r Program committee\r* Yogesh S Rawat, University of Central Florida, USA\r* Pravin Nagar, University of Maryland, USA\r* Pradeep K Atrey, State University of New York, USA\r* Wolfgang H\xc3\xbcrst, Utrecht University, the Netherlands\r* Albert Ali Salah, Utrecht University, the Netherlands\r* Evlampios Apostolidis, Information Technologies Institute, CERTH, Thessaloniki, GREECE\r* Daniela D\'Auria, Free University of Bolzano, Italy\r* Takahiro Komamizu, Nagoya University, Japan\r* Yongqing Sun, NTT, Japan\r* Masakazu Iwamura, Osaka Metropolitan University, Japan\r* Jien Kato, Ritsumeikan University, Japan\r* Junnan Li, Salesforce Research Asia, Singapore\r* Tian Gan, Shandong University, China\r* Lin Li, Wuhan University of Technology, China\r* Ramanathan Subramanian, University of Canberra, Australia\r* Cathal Gurrin, Dublin City University, Ireland\r* Rajiv Ratn Shah, Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology, Delhi, India\r ------------------------------\rCONTACT\r------------------------------\rEmail: narsum.cf@gmail.com\rTwitter: @NarSUM_WS\r For more information, please visit the workshop website, https://narsum.cf/\r=====================================================================================\n\t'

Call For Papers: b'\nThe 12th IEEE International Conference on Smart Computing, Networking and Services\rSmartCNS 2022\rChongqing, China\r December 19 - 21, 2022.\rhttp://smartcns2022.cqupt.edu.cn/index.html\r  Call for Papers\r===============\r SmartCNS-2022 is the 12th edition of the highly successful International Conference on Computer and Information Technology. The goal of the conference is to provide a forum for scientists, engineers and researchers to discuss and exchange novel ideas, results, experiences and work-in-process on all aspects of computer and information technology. SmartCNS has become a major platform for researchers and industry practitioners from different fields of computer and information technology. Each year, SmartCNS attendees appreciate and benefit from multidisciplinary exchanges in computer and information technology. In previous years, SmartCNS has attracted many high-quality research papers spanning over the various aspects of information technology, computing science and computer engineering. title: b'IJCNC 2022'
description: b'Special Issue on: Energy-Aware Wireless Sensor Networks for Precision Agriculture '
Categories: b'computer science' b'engineering' b'communications' b'machine learning'
Call For Papers: b'\n Special Issue on: "Energy-Aware Wireless Sensor Networks for Precision Agriculture" Guest Editors:Raja Krishnamoorthi CMR Engineering College, Telangana, India. A. Shanthini SRM Institute of Science and Technology, India Bouziane BRIKBurgundy (Bourgogne) university, France  Adhiyaman ManickamUniversity of Moncton, Canada Theme and ScopeIn today\'s world, several technological trends influenced various fields, and the agricultural sector is also included without any doubt. The smart wireless sensor network is one of the great research topis among the modest technologies seeking greater attention worldwide due to its broad range of commercial significance. Advanced sensors and sensing technologies significantly impact everyday aspects of people\'s lives since they can positively transform the process and manage agricultural practices, resulting in the development of precision agriculture.Agriculture has been facing a crucial challenge in recent days to please the needs of the rising population without draining the available resources. Hence, energy-aware wireless sensor networks come into action in innovative agricultural industries. Precision agriculture is the science that employs data from various sources to facilitate agricultural production and increase environmentally friendly crop management techniques. The advancing sensor network like WSNs (Wireless Sensor Networks) and IoT (Internet of Things) implied networks play a vital role in monitoring agricultural yield, fertilizer requirements, groundwater monitoring, plant mapping, pest management, etc. sensor node of WSNs aids in monitoring the environmental conditions like humidity, rainfall, the temperature which is the significant criteria for the cultivation process in the precision agriculture-intending at better energy consumption for emerging protocols that contribute to mitigating the energy consumption of sensing technology considerably. The incorporation of WSNs is expected to bring out substantial changes in precision agriculture, which aids in the development of disease management processes and pest control system in an agricultural field. IoT-assisted drone system permits efficient monitoring in intelligent farming, animal husbandry management, and livestock. Research envisaged that amalgamation of WSNs with other technological features is found to have numerous applications when implied for agriculture like big data analytics, cloud computing, IoT. In specific UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) and 6G wireless communication technology aids to provide more excellent benefits in the groundwater monitoring, this shows higher growth in precision agriculture. This special issue is intended to cover contributions in all aspects of cloud-centric and outsourced computing such as a Service, Categories, Network, Infrastructure, Platform, Function and software.\r The special issue provides myriad opportunities for scholars and academicians to discuss the securing implementing WSNs in precision agriculture. Despite having many beneficial trends, it also holds certain limitations to be observed. Limitations indulge in technical errors, data loss, privacy threats, hacking issues, high-cost implications, and lack of technical knowledge. Researchers and practitioners are invited to present a theoretical research work against this background.Topics of interest include, but are not limited to: Authors are solicited to contribute to this special Issue by submitting articles that illustrate research results, projects, surveying works and industrial experiences that describe significant advances in the following areas, but are not limited to Emerging trends and application of Energy-aware WSNs in precision agriculture\rImportance of technical knowledge in wireless sensor networks\rRole of the internet of things in empowering precision agriculture\rLimitations and downsides of the wireless network for precision agriculture\rEnergy aware wireless sensor networks for sustainable agriculture: trends, perspectives, \rand future applications\rFuture perspective of big data analytics for energy efficiency analysis and sustainable \rprecision agriculture\rAdvancement of the wireless network for precision agriculture in the coming era: An\rEnergy Perspective\rRole of WSN based drones for the enhancement of precise agricultural practices\rProtocols of wireless sensor networks for the development of precision agriculture\rNeed for Long-Range wireless technology networks for energy aware intelligent \ragriculture: frontiers and applications\rNeed for sustainable energy aware policies to incorporate smart sensor applications in \rprecision agricultureNotes for Prospective AuthorsSubmissions must be original and should not have been published previously or be under consideration for publication while being evaluated for this Issue. Manuscripts should be written in English and strictly follow the guideline of the Journal IJCNC. The manuscripts should be submitted to one of the guest editors by December 12, 2022 through email  wsn2022@aircconline.comImportant Dates Submission Deadline:December 12, 2022 Authors Notification: March 10, 2023Final Manuscript Due: June 06, 2023 For more details please visit:  https://airccse.org/journal/ijcnc.html \n'
Related Resources:
b'

Special Issue on: "Energy-Aware Wireless Sensor Networks for Precision Agriculture"

Guest Editors:

Raja Krishnamoorthi
CMR Engineering College, Telangana, India.

A. Shanthini
SRM Institute of Science and Technology, India

Bouziane BRIK
Burgundy (Bourgogne) university, France

Adhiyaman Manickam
University of Moncton, Canada

Theme and Scope

In today\'s world, several technological trends influenced various fields, and the agricultural sector is also included without any doubt. The smart wireless sensor network is one of the great research topis among the modest technologies seeking greater attention worldwide due to its broad range of commercial significance. Advanced sensors and sensing technologies significantly impact everyday aspects of people\'s lives since they can positively transform the process and manage agricultural practices, resulting in the development of precision agriculture.

Agriculture has been facing a crucial challenge in recent days to please the needs of the rising population without draining the available resources. Hence, energy-aware wireless sensor networks come into action in innovative agricultural industries. Precision agriculture is the science that employs data from various sources to facilitate agricultural production and increase environmentally friendly crop management techniques. The advancing sensor network like WSNs (Wireless Sensor Networks) and IoT (Internet of Things) implied networks play a vital role in monitoring agricultural yield, fertilizer requirements, groundwater monitoring, plant mapping, pest management, etc. sensor node of WSNs aids in monitoring the environmental conditions like humidity, rainfall, the temperature which is the significant criteria for the cultivation process in the precision agriculture-intending at better energy consumption for emerging protocols that contribute to mitigating the energy consumption of sensing technology considerably.

The incorporation of WSNs is expected to bring out substantial changes in precision agriculture, which aids in the development of disease management processes and pest control system in an agricultural field. IoT-assisted drone system permits efficient monitoring in intelligent farming, animal husbandry management, and livestock. Research envisaged that amalgamation of WSNs with other technological features is found to have numerous applications when implied for agriculture like big data analytics, cloud computing, IoT. In specific UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) and 6G wireless communication technology aids to provide more excellent benefits in the groundwater monitoring, this shows higher growth in precision agriculture. This special issue is intended to cover contributions in all aspects of cloud-centric and outsourced computing such as a Service, Categories, Network, Infrastructure, Platform, Function and software.\r

The special issue provides myriad opportunities for scholars and academicians to discuss the securing implementing WSNs in precision agriculture. Despite having many beneficial trends, it also holds certain limitations to be observed. Limitations indulge in technical errors, data loss, privacy threats, hacking issues, high-cost implications, and lack of technical knowledge. Researchers and practitioners are invited to present a theoretical research work against this background.

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

Authors are solicited to contribute to this special Issue by submitting articles that illustrate research results, projects, surveying works and industrial experiences that describe significant advances in the following areas, but are not limited to


  • Emerging trends and application of Energy-aware WSNs in precision agriculture\r
  • Importance of technical knowledge in wireless sensor networks\r
  • Role of the internet of things in empowering precision agriculture\r
  • Limitations and downsides of the wireless network for precision agriculture\r
  • Energy aware wireless sensor networks for sustainable agriculture: trends, perspectives, \r
    and future applications\r
  • Future perspective of big data analytics for energy efficiency analysis and sustainable \r
    precision agriculture\r
  • Advancement of the wireless network for precision agriculture in the coming era: An\r
    Energy Perspective\r
  • Role of WSN based drones for the enhancement of precise agricultural practices\r
  • Protocols of wireless sensor networks for the development of precision agriculture\r
  • Need for Long-Range wireless technology networks for energy aware intelligent \r
    agriculture: frontiers and applications\r
  • Need for sustainable energy aware policies to incorporate smart sensor applications in \r
    precision agriculture

Notes for Prospective Authors

Submissions must be original and should not have been published previously or be under consideration for publication while being evaluated for this Issue. Manuscripts should be written in English and strictly follow the guideline of the Journal IJCNC. The manuscripts should be submitted to one of the guest editors by December 12, 2022 through email wsn2022@aircconline.com

Important Dates

Submission Deadline:December 12, 2022
Authors Notification: March 10, 2023
Final Manuscript Due: June 06, 2023

For more details please visit: https://airccse.org/journal/ijcnc.html

title: b'DSM 2022'
description: b'FIRST INTERNATIONAL SUMMER SCHOOL ON DATA SCIENCE FOR MOBILITY'
Categories: b'summer school' b'data science' b'mobility data' b'data analysis'
Call For Papers: b'\nFIRST INTERNATIONAL SUMMER SCHOOL ON DATA SCIENCE FOR MOBILITY\rOctober 3 - 7, 2022\rKastelli Resort, Kamari Village, Santorini, Greece\rhttp://master-school.isti.cnr.it\r  ***** Deadline approaching: August 31, 2022 *****\r  *** Call for Participation ***\r MOTIVATION \rMassive amounts of Spatio-temporal data representing trajectories of moving objects are produced by an ever-increasing number of diverse, real-life applications, ranging from mobile to social media apps and surveillance systems, from vehicle tracking systems to IoT mobile sensors. Such mobility-aware traces come in huge numbers and very complex forms and can be enriched with multiple different semantic dimensions. These semantically enriched trajectories have the potential to unveil novel challenges in several domains, such as urban, maritime and aviation.\r The explosion in Data Science is happening now. The Big Data technological infrastructure has reached maturity. Significant interest from the research community is being shown towards the Big Data Value Analytics reference model: data management, data processing, data analytics, data visualization. The time is right for the field of Mobility Data Science to follow the trend!\r Our First Summer School on Data Science for Mobility offers participants both visionary keynote speeches and hands-on mini-courses held by leading experts in AI and Data Analytics for Mobility from Canada, Greece & Italy. The keynotes speeches will explore the challenges faced due to the voluminous and complex mobility data generated every day in maritime and aviation domains. The hands-on mini-courses complement the keynotes by giving practical experience in the usage of analysis tools on real mobility datasets.\r  TARGET GROUPS\rThis Summer School is intended for PhD students, researchers and practitioners in the fields of Computer and Information Science, interested in learning about the most recent developments in mobility data science. Attendees will familiarise themselves with the most recent data science trends, including deep learning and AI methods for mobility data, methods to analyze human mobility as well as with methods for big mobility data. With the hands-on experience, participants will gain familiarity with some commonly used tools and datasets.\r  COURSE AIM\rAt the end of the course, each attendee will:\r ** Understand how to analyze mobility data with deep learning techniques\r** Understand how machine learning and AI methods can be tailored to mobility data\r** Understand how to manage Big Mobility Data\r** Gain significant hands-on experience with state-of-the-art technologies and tools\r** Have a vision of open research as well as technological challenges customized to key application areas and domains\r  KEYNOTE SPEAKERS\rProf. Goce Trajcevski Iowa State University (USA)\rProf. George Vouros, University of Piraeus (Greece)\r  HANDS-ON MINI COURSES\r Title: Deep Learning for Mobility\rTutors: Franco Maria Nardini & Salvatore Trani (ISTI-CNR, Italy)\r Title: Human mobility analysis and simulation in Python\rTutors: Luca Pappalardo (ISTI-CNR, Italy)\r Title: Learning from our movements: Big Mobility Data Analytics\rTutors: Yannis Theodoridis (Data Science Lab, University of Piraeus, Greece) & Panagiotis Tampakis (Department of Mathematics and Computer Science of the University of Southern Denmark, Denmark)\r  PANEL: Emerging issues on mobility data science\r The objective of this panel session is to highlight the emerging issues that relate to the analysis of mobility data and their applications. Examples of such issues could revolve around: datasets, AI approaches, privacy compromise, unethical use of analysis products and others. The audience will get the chance to participate in a live discussion with experts in the field from academia and industry, who will share their opinions, in a moderated open discussion.\r Panelists (initial list):\r Prof. George Vouros, University of Piraeus (Greece)\rDr. Thierry Chevallier (AKKA Technologies, France) \rProf. Bettina Berendt (Technische Universit\xc3\xa4t Berlin, Germany & KU Leuven, Belgium)\rDr. Franco Maria Nardini (ISTI-CNR, Italy)\rDr. Luca Pappalardo (ISTI-CNR, Italy)\rProf. Yannis Theodoridis (University of Piraeus, Greece)\r Moderator: Konstantinos Tserpes (Harokopio University, Greece)\r  REGISTRATION\r Registration fee is 300 euro.  \rDetails on the registration procedure, deadlines and the school schedule are available at the school web site: http://master-school.isti.cnr.it\r  VENUE\r The Summer School will be held at the Kastelli Resort on the magic island of Santorini, in Greece.\rhttps://www.kastelliresort.com\rhttp://www.santorini.gr/index.php?lang=en\r  ACCOMMODATIONS\r  The Summer School has NOT reserved rooms for the school. All the participants are warmly invited to reserve their accommodation on their own as soon as possible.\r *** Kastelli Resort, the venue of the Summer School, is a peaceful luxury retreat that combines an idyllic and convenient location, with upscale accommodation, state-of-the-art facilities, and impeccable services.\r *** Dioskouri Art Villas is a 3* boutique hotel situated in a central and quiet area of the village Kamari in Santorini, near Kamari Beach. The hotel is two minutes walking from the venue of the summer school.\r For details check instructions at: http://master-school.isti.cnr.it/accomodation/\r  SOCIAL PROGRAM\r The Data Science for Mobility school offers a rich social program, including a Welcome cocktail with dinner on Monday 3rd, the trip to Oia to admire the famous Santorini sunset, and a wine tasting experience with the Caldera view. All details are available at: http://master-school.isti.cnr.it/social-program/\r  GENERAL CHAIRS\r Nikos Pelekis \rUniversity of Piraeus (Greece)\r Chiara Renso \rISTI-CNR (Italy)\r ORGANIZATION and PUBLICITY CHAIR\rBeatrice Rapisarda (ISTI-CNR) \r REGISTRATION CHAIR \rYannis Kontoulis (University of Piraeus, Greece)\r PANEL CHAIR \rKonstantinos Tserpes (Harokopio University, Greece)\r ORGANIZATION COMMITTEE \rJose Fernandes da Macedo (Federal University of Ceara\xe2\x80\x99, Brazil) \rRaffaele Perego (ISTI-CNR, Italy) \rAlessandra Raffaeta\xe2\x80\x99 (University Ca\xe2\x80\x99 Foscari of Venice, Italy) \rAmilcar Soares (Memorial University of Newfoundland, Canada) \rYannis Theodoridis (University of Piraeus, Greece) \rKarine Zeitouni (University of Versailles Saint Quentin, France) \r  SPONSORS\r This Summer School is organized and supported by H2020 MSCA project MASTER GA 777695 http://www.master-project-h2020.eu and sponsored by H2020 VesselAI  GA 957237  https://vessel-ai.eu/ and H2020 MOBIDATALAB GA 101006879 http://www.mobidatalab.eu \r  CONTACT US\rFor further information: master-summer-chairs AT isti.cnr.it\n\t'

title: b'CMO 2022'
description: b'Collective Memory & Oral tradition: Explorations and Interpretations'
Categories: b'education' b'oral history' b'memory' b'collective identity'
Call For Papers: b"\nCollective Memory & Oral tradition: Explorations and Interpretations\r International Conference\r20-21 July 2022\r(Zoom sessions:2 days-Virtual platform:5 days)\r Thematic Approach\r GIRES is committed to creating a welcoming space for discussion, collaboration, and exploration of oral history\xe2\x80\x99s potential as a tool for local, national, and international projects that would enrich and even revise chapters of history. \r Our new international conference seeks to promote the importance of oral history as a valuable and unique source of information. For decades, oral history was considered less than scholarly, leading to its exclusion from several history books; thus valuable first-hand experiences and information that could alter historical truth were neglected and ultimately lost to oblivion. We wish to challenge the pervading view that oral testimony can lead to false representation of historical events; and underline the significant support they can provide to historical research, especially in lieu of written documentation. \r We also hope to focus on the connections between oral history, collective memory, and individual memory. Whether from a historical, social, or even psychological approach we wish to engage scholars in a multidimensional and interdisciplinary approach in order to deeply explore all aspects of this valuable and fascinating discipline. \r We invite scholars from different fields including history, philosophy, religion, sociology, international relations, literature, art, space studies, peace studies, cultural studies, minority studies, war and/or genocide studies, journalism, immigration studies, psychology and psychiatry, political and social studies, and those working in archives, museums and NGOs. \r Proposed Topics \r -Oral history throughout history\r-Oral historian: a public historian? Oral history as a form of social and communal activity;\r-Conducting oral history research: Methodologies and techniques\r-Re-examining and re-writing history through the lens of oral history\r-Epistemological and ethical dilemmas in oral history\r-Collective/Individual memory and oral tradition\r-Manipulation of memory and the role of oral history\r-Oral history and trauma\r-Oral history as a tool of revealing/reliving a dictatorship/suppressing regime\r-Altering, exaggerating or forgetting memories; the psychology of a survivor\r-Oral history in teaching and teaching oral history\r Proposed Formats (Lingua franca: English)\r-Individual papers (GIRES will included it in a panel)\r-Panels (up to 4 presentations-chaired by one of the presenters or appointed by GIRES)\r-Roundtable presentations (chaired by one of the presenters or appointed by GIRES)\r-Poster presentations\r-Student presentations (one paper presented by up to 3 young scholars)\r-Keynote speech (depending on the time availability)\r-Pre-recorder presentation (s) (Asynchronous Platform)\r-Pre-recorder presentation (s) (Synchronous-live- Sessions: live participation of presenter (s) during the Q&A sessions)\r Publication Opportunity \rThe Organizing Committee and GIRES Press will publish the most powerful and dynamic presentations of the conference and include them\rin a collective volume in the form of short articles and/or long essays. For more information please contact us\r Live Sessions & Recording\rAll speakers are offered up to 30 minutes to present their work. All speakers have the option to have their presentations recorded (during live sessions) in HD quality.\rThe recordings will be uploaded to GIRES media for unlimited access and dissemination.\r Asynchronous Options\rAll participants have the option to have their presentations (video/audio/text) uploaded to our Virtual Platform. All  registered participants will have access to the material for 5 days.\r   PROPOSAL SUBMISSION  (Please use our online application form found in the conference's webpage)\rDEADLINE FOR PROPOSALS: July 12,  2022\rACCEPTANCE NOTIFICATION: July 15, 2022\rPUBLICATION: GIRES PRESS \rACCREDITATION: Official Certificate Issued by GIRES \r ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\rGenerating dialogue is of primary importance for our scholarly community and thus GIRES wishes to create a friendly and welcoming environment for all of our colleagues and offer all the tools to present their work in the best possible way.\r----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\r Our proposed topics & formats are not restrictive and we invite additional germane ideas\rDue to the restrictions of Corona Crisis our event (for the time being) will take place virtually\r Contact Info: \rGIRES-GLOBAL INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH, EDUCATION & SCHOLARSHIP (Amsterdam, The Netherlands)\rwww.gires.org (Dr. Konstantinos D. Karatzas-Director & Chloe Matias, Communication Officer)\r Contact Email: \rinfo@gires.org\rURL: \rhttps://www.gires.org/activities/conferences/collective-memory-and-oral-tradition-explorations-and-interpretations-4/\r\n"

title: b'Cancer Therapeutics 2022'
description: b'Side Effects of Gastrointestinal Cancer Therapeutics'
Categories: b'oncology' b'surgery' b'gastroenterology' b'hepatology'
Call For Papers: b'\nSide Effects of Gastrointestinal Cancer Therapeutics\r \xe2\x80\x9cThe employment of non-surgical treatment options for gastrointestinal cancer has greatly assisted late-stage patients. However, we need to further investigate the impacts of these options to reduce unwanted side effects and improve the quality of life for patients.\xe2\x80\x9d Special Issue Editor Dr. Jian Zhang, Attending Surgeon, Senior researcher, Sun Yat-Sen University of Medical Sciences\r Gastrointestinal cancer is a leading cause of cancer death worldwide, especially in some regions of Asia. Major advances in cancer therapeutics have led to a remarkable reduction in gastrointestinal cancer mortality. However, these improvements come with the limitation of a range of side effects, that affect most patients with varying severity, and that clinicians and researchers need to treat and investigate. With the emergence of new therapeutics, such as immunotherapy, improving our understanding of therapy-related side effects is a vital and meaningful goal.\r \xe2\x80\x9cNew results are emerging in the field of non-surgical treatment of gastrointestinal tumors, but the application of these results is limited due to the existence of side effects of treatment. It is hoped that this special issue will enable us to make a systematic summary of related fields and inspire future research.\xe2\x80\x9d Special Issue Editor Dr Dongjie Yang, Consultant, First Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University\r For this Special Issue, we particularly encourage the submission of manuscripts dealing with any aspect of side effect analyses for gastrointestinal cancer, including, but not limited to, acute and chronic side effects, immunotherapy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy et al. We welcome manuscripts in the form of original research or literature reviews.\r Topics\r Including, but not limited to:\r Gastric Cancer\rColorectal Cancer\rCancer Biology\rImmunotherapy\rChemotherapy\rRadiotherapy\rCardiotoxicity\rNeuropathy\rFatigue\rGastrointestinal\rNephrotoxicity\rImmune-Related\rSexual Dysfunction\rCognitive Changes\rRisk Factors And Risk Prediction\rPharmacogenetics/Pharmacogenomics\r For more information and to submit your abstract, please visit:  https://peerj.com/special-issues/108-gastro-cancer-side-effects\r \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x93\n\t'

title: b'ARIS2 JOURNAL 2022'
description: b'CFP - Advanced Research on Information Systems Security, an Internacional Journal'
Categories: b'cybersecurity' b'hacking' b'forensics' b'law'
Call For Papers: b'\nCALL FOR PAPERS\r 1st Edition 2022\r Dear Colleague,\r The ARIS2 cordially invites you to submit your scientific work to the first edition of 2022, to be published on July 30th.\r With the constant rise of products and services available through the web, the fact that these operate with sensible user information and data, harmful entities and subjects are increasingly active in the virtual world.\r With the everyday improvement of defensive methods, cybercriminals recur to extremely sophisticated skills to perform their malicious activities. While protecting the privacy of users, many technologies found in current malware and network attacks have been abused in order to allow criminals to carry out their undertakings unobserved. This panorama poses a lot of new challenges for digital forensics analysts, academics, law enforcement agencies (LEAs), and security professionals.\r The aim of the ARIS2 is to bring together MSc., Doctoral students, general researchers, practitioners, tech companies, law enforcement agencies/representatives, and security professionals in the area of information security forensics and data privacy, to learn from their work and prominent research.\r This Volume 2, Edition1 of 2022, aims to present a more complete picture of novel research regarding information security, data leakage protection & prevention challenges, and how criminals undertake their actions.\r Topics and Areas of Interest (not limited to):\r Artificial Intelligence in Cybersecurity\rBig data and cybersecurity\rBusiness continuity and disaster recovery\rChild safety in the cyberspace\rCloud security\rCritical infrastructure security\rCyber forensics\rCyber insurance\rCyberwarfare\rCybersecurity and cyber resilience\rDigital currency, blockchains, and cybercrime\rDigital privacy\rEmbedded systems security\rHealthcare information security\rInformation security governance\rInternet of things security\rLaw, investigation, internet jurisdiction, and ethics\rNetwork security\rSecurity management\rSoftware development security\rSurveillance, interception, blocking, and sovereignty\rImportant dates:\r Publication: July 30, 2022\rYours sincerely,\rNuno Mateus-Coelho, PhD\rEditor-in-Chief\n\t'

title: b'PPoPP 2023'
description: b'PPoPP 2023 : The 27th ACM SIGPLAN Annual Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming'
Call For Papers: b'\nPPoPP 2023: 28th ACM SIGPLAN Annual Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming\r Montreal, Canada. (collocated with CC-2023, HPCA-2023 and CGO-2023) Dates: 25 February - 1 March, 2023.\r Submission URL: https://ppopp23.hotcrp.com\r # Important dates:\r     Full paper submission: August 17, 2022\r    Author response period: October 26\xe2\x80\x93October 28, 2022\r    Author notification: November 7, 2022\r    Artifact submission to AE committee: November 16, 2022\r    Artifact notification by AE committee: December 30, 2022\r    Final paper due: January 6, 2023\r All deadlines are at midnight anywhere on earth (AoE), and are firm.\r # Scope:\r PPoPP is the premier forum for leading work on all aspects of parallel programming, including theoretical foundations, techniques, languages, compilers, runtime systems, tools, and practical experience. In the context of the symposium, \xe2\x80\x9cparallel programming\xe2\x80\x9d encompasses work on concurrent and parallel systems (multicore, multi-threaded, heterogeneous, clustered, and distributed systems; grids; data centers; clouds; and large scale machines). Given the rise of parallel architectures in the consumer market (desktops, laptops, and mobile devices) and data centers, PPoPP is particularly interested in work that addresses new parallel workloads and issues that arise out of extreme-scale applications or cloud platforms, as well as techniques and tools that improve the productivity of parallel programming or work towards improved synergy with such emerging architectures.\r Specific topics of interest include (but are not limited to):\r     Compilers and runtime systems for parallel and heterogeneous systems\r    Concurrent data structures\r    Development, analysis, or management tools\r    Fault tolerance for parallel systems\r    Formal analysis and verification\r    High-performance / scientific computing\r    Libraries\r    Middleware for parallel systems\r    Parallel algorithms\r    Parallel applications and frameworks\r    Parallel programming for deep memory hierarchies including nonvolatile memory\r    Parallel programming languages\r    Parallel programming theory and models\r    Parallelism in non-scientific workloads: web, search, analytics, cloud, machine learning\r    Performance analysis, debugging and optimization\r    Programming tools for parallel and heterogeneous systems\r    Software engineering for parallel programs\r    Software for heterogeneous architectures\r    Software productivity for parallel programming\r    Synchronization and concurrency control\r Papers should report on original research relevant to parallel programming and should contain enough background materials to make them accessible to the entire parallel programming research community. Papers describing experience should indicate how they illustrate general principles or lead to new insights; papers about parallel programming foundations should indicate how they relate to practice. PPoPP submissions will be evaluated based on their technical merit and accessibility. Submissions should clearly motivate the importance of the problem being addressed, compare to the existing body of work on the topic, and explicitly and precisely state the paper\xe2\x80\x99s key contributions and results towards addressing the problem. Submissions should strive to be accessible both to a broad audience and to experts in the area.\r # Paper Submission:\r Conference submission site: https://ppopp23.hotcrp.com.\r All submissions must be made electronically through the conference web site and include an abstract (100\xe2\x80\x93400 words), author contact information, the full list of authors and their affiliations. Full paper submissions must be in PDF formatted printable on both A4 and US letter size paper.\r All papers must be prepared in ACM Conference Format using the 2-column acmart format: use the SIGPLAN proceedings template acmart-sigplanproc-template.tex for Latex,and interim-layout.docx for Word. You may also want to consult the official ACM information on the Master Article Template and related tools. Important note: The Word template (interim-layout.docx) on the ACM website uses 9pt font; you need to increase it to 10pt.\r Papers should contain a maximum of 10 pages of text (in a typeface no smaller than 10 point) or figures, NOT INCLUDING references. There is no page limit for references and they must include the name of all authors (not {et al.}). Appendices are not allowed, but the authors may submit supplementary material, such as proofs or source code; all supplementary material must be in PDF or ZIP format. Looking at supplementary material is at the discretion of the reviewers.\r Submission is double blind and authors will need to identify any potential conflicts of interest with PC and Extended Review Committee members, as defined here: http://www.sigplan.org/Resources/Policies/Review/ (ACM SIGPLAN policy).\r PPoPP 2023 will employ a double-blind reviewing process. To facilitate this process, submissions should not reveal the identity of the authors in any way. Authors should leave out author names and affiliations from the body of their submission. They should also ensure that any references to authors\xe2\x80\x99 own related work should be in the third person (e.g., not \xe2\x80\x9cWe build on our previous work \xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d but rather \xe2\x80\x9cWe build on the work of \xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d). The purpose of this process is to help the PC and external reviewers come to an initial judgment about the paper without bias, not to make it impossible for them to discover the authors if they were to try. Nothing should be done in the name of anonymity that weakens the submission or makes the job of reviewing the paper more difficult. In particular, important background references should not be omitted or anonymized. In addition, authors should feel free to disseminate their ideas or draft versions of their paper as they normally would. For instance, authors may post drafts of their papers on the web or give talks on their research ideas. Authors with further questions on double-blind reviewing are encouraged to contact the Program Chairs by email.\r Submissions should be in PDF and printable on both US Letter and A4 paper. Papers may be resubmitted to the submission site multiple times up until the deadline, but the last version submitted before the deadline will be the version reviewed. Papers that exceed the length requirement, that deviate from the expected format, or that are submitted late will be rejected.\r All submissions that are not accepted for regular presentations will be automatically considered for posters. Two-page summaries of accepted posters will be included in the conference proceedings.\r To allow reproducibility, we encourage authors of accepted papers to submit their papers for Artifact Evaluation (AE). The AE process begins after the acceptance notification, and is run by a separate committee whose task is to assess how the artifacts support the work described in the papers. Artifact evaluation is voluntary and will not affect paper acceptance, but will be taken into consideration when selecting papers for awards. Papers that go through the AE process successfully will receive one or several of the ACM reproducibility badges, printed on the papers themselves. More information will be posted on the AE website.\r Deadlines expire at midnight anywhere on earth.\r  # Workshop/Tutorial Proposals:\r We are soliciting proposals for workshops and tutorials within the general scope of PPoPP. Members of the community are encouraged to submit proposals for workshops/tutorials that bring together researchers and practitioners to share their tools, technologies, latest results and to discuss work in progress and new directions. Please submit proposals to the PPoPP 2023 Workshops and Tutorials Chair, Zoran Budimli\xc4\x87 (zoran@tamu.edu). Workshop and tutorial proposals will be evaluated on an ongoing basis. Early submissions are encouraged and will be evaluated immediately. Please note that for workshops that wish to publish accepted submissions in the ACM Digital Library special rules apply. Such workshops also require approval by the SIGPLAN executive committee. The key dates are as follows:\r     Proposal submission deadline: September 16, 2022 (AoE)\r    Final notification of acceptance: September 30, 2022\r    Workshop/tutorial dates: February 25-26, 2023\r\n'

title: b'Intel4EC 2022'
description: b'International Workshop on Intelligent and Adaptive Edge-Cloud Operations and Services collocated with IEEE/ACM Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC 2022)'
Categories: b'cloud computing' b'edge computing' b'big data' b'AIOPS'
Call For Papers: b'\nScope:\r The emergence of Computing Continuum with ever-expanding Cloud boundaries and its evolution into the proverbial Fog, Edge, and IoT paradigms has paved the way for realizing transformational and innovative digital solutions. Emerging application areas such as smart transportation logistics, smart cities, healthcare, and industry 4.0 sectors encompassing highly distributed services that use many devices involving large-scale data generation, gathering, storage, and analysis in real-time further encourage its adoption. While the geo-distributed and federated nature of the continuum continues to improve the agility, responsiveness, and effectiveness of such distributed applications. This paradigmatic shift in the post-digital transformation era has also triggered drastically changing expectations of dynamic service deployment and infrastructure usage patterns, further introducing significant complexities to the Edge-Cloud management layers. These include challenges related to performance sustainability, sprawl management, resilience, and scalability of massive digital operations and services. These issues break down to reconciling many and typically allude to dynamically changing demand, requirements, and constraints of digital applications, which require the Edge-Cloud infrastructures to be deployed in sites that are in large numbers and are sometimes located in remote areas. To manage such fault-prone Edge-Cloud systems, infrastructure and service providers rely on human-intensive means to meet the increasing capacity demand and high availability of digital services. However, due to the continuously changing landscape, utilizing manual interventions to manage such large-scale systems is implausible. Hence, mitigating such issues requires digital applications and Edge-Cloud infrastructure to reposition their focus from adopting more efficient, effective, quick, and cheap compute capabilities to embracing more autonomous and self-driven technologies.  \r Recently, Intelligent Cloud Operations and Services (a.k.a AIOps) gained traction that advocates using AI/ML techniques to embed intelligence at the Edge-Cloud management layers and automate digital operations and services by only requiring human intervention for critical issues beyond automation capabilities. While AIOps is still in an emerging phase, academia and industry foresee many possible advancements ranging from root-cause analysis, early anomaly detection, and mitigation to predictive and prescriptive maintenance and management in Edge-Cloud systems. Additionally, such AIOps powered transformation can ensure that the continuum supply chain meets the heightened user demands in terms of openness, security, privacy and resilience, energy and resource efficiency and provide Cloud-Edge technologies with an ability to scale, accelerate innovation and enable industry-specific needs.\r The Intel4EC workshop aims to bring together researchers, developers and practitioners from academia and industry to present their experiences, results and research progress covering architectural designs, methods and applications of AI/ML-enabled Edge-Cloud operations and services. By bringing together these research topics, Intel4EC looks forward to help the community define open standards, AI/ML benchmarks that contribute to experiment reproducibility and systematize the complete management pipeline for a myriad of Cloud-Edge operations.\r Intel4EC 2022 workshop aims to attract the Cloud, Fog, Edge, Big Data, AI/ML and distributed computing community for novel research contributions to intelligent, adaptive, manageable and observable Edge-Cloud systems that include topics of interest, but are not limited to:\r Performance instrumentation, monitoring and observability\rCausal attribution and root-cause analysis\rPerformance diagnosis and prognosis\rFailure prediction and fault localisation\rAnomaly detection and prediction\rChaos engineering and analytics\rCapacity planning, scalability and workload management\rEdge-Cloud sprawl management and multi-tenancy issues\rAI/ML techniques for cost and energy-efficient operations\rAdaptive resource provisioning, scheduling and run-time optimisation\rTrust, security and privacy-preserving AI/ML\rSLA breach, violation and vulnerability detection\rService discovery and microservice composition\rIntelligent programming models\rDistributed data (e.g. logs, traces) integration, management and analysis\rSelf-adaptive and self-healing systems\rExperiment reproducibility, benchmarks, and application case-studies\r Submission Guidelines:\r The Intel4EC workshop invites original research papers that have not been previously published and are not currently under review for publication elsewhere. Following paper categories are welcome:\r Regular Full Papers: Full research papers should describe the original work and be no longer than 6 pages (+ 2 for additional fee).\r Short Papers: Short research papers up to 4 pages in length, should contain enough information for the program committee to understand the scope of the project and evaluate the novelty of the problem or approach.\r All manuscripts should adhere to page limits and be submitted in PDF using IEEE format. Each paper submitted to the workshop will be peer-reviewed by a minimum of three technical program committee members and will be evaluated on the basis of scientific significance, originality, technical quality, correctness, presentation, and relevance to the workshop attendees. The workshop proceedings will be published by IEEE in the same or a companion volume as the UCC 2022 conference. At least one author of each accepted manuscript must register in full and attend the workshop to present the paper. Any workshop participant must register under the UCC 2022 workshop day registration fee or the conference fee.\r Submission Page:\rhttps://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=intel4ec\r Special Journal Issue:\r Selected papers from the Intel4EC workshop will be invited for submission of extended version for publication to Springer\xe2\x80\x99s Journal of Cloud Computing: Advances Systems and Applications (JoCCASA) special issue.\r Important Dates:\rSubmission Deadline: September 8th, 2022\rNotification of Acceptance: October 5th, 2022\rCamera-ready and Registration: October 15th, 2022\rAll deadlines are indicated as 23:59 AoE (Anywhere on Earth)\r\n'
